children.text: ***	In keeping with paragraph 10 of General Assembly resolution 77/267, the part consisting of the post and non-post resource requirements (part III) is submitted through the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions for the consideration of the Assembly.
A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

18.1	The Economic Commission for Africa (ECA) is responsible for promoting the economic and social development of its members, fostering intraregional integration and promoting international cooperation for the development of Africa. The mandate derives from the priorities established in relevant General Assembly resolutions and decisions, and Economic and Social Council resolution 671 A (XXV).

18.2	ECA provides innovative solutions, together with demand-driven and tailor-made policy and technical advice, grounded in evidence, to its members and regional economic communities to strengthen their social and economic resilience and achieve the goals of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and Agenda 2063: The Africa We Want, of the African Union. ECA is well positioned to support member States, within its mandate, in the implementation of relevant commitments and actions outlined in the Pact for the Future (General Assembly resolution 79/1). ECA also works to build the capacity of its members to formulate and implement policies for sustainable development, including through the implementation of the regular programme for technical cooperation and United Nations Development Account projects.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
18.3	In 2026, ECA will concentrate on five strategic directions:

(a)	Deploying knowledge to support policymaking to drive the development agenda of Africa and foster infrastructure development, including in the areas of energy; technology, innovation and connectivity; and climate action and food security;
(b)	Formulating policy options, including macroeconomic policies, to accelerate sustainable industrialization and economic diversification;
(c)	Enhancing the mainstreaming of data and statistics, designing and implementing financing models and leveraging them for the development of human, physical and social infrastructure assets;

(d)	Supporting deeper regional integration and the development of regional public goods, focusing on social inclusion and considering synergies between the economic and social development programmes of Africa;
(e)	Advocating a common position for Africa at the global level and developing regional responses as a contribution to global governance issues.

18.4	Within its existing mandate, and in line with the actions and decisions contained in the Pact for the Future and the commitments contained in the Global Digital Compact and the Declaration on Future Generations, ECA will pay particular attention to supporting member States in leveraging technology and artificial intelligence for economic and social development and promoting digital cooperation, as well as further developing sustainable regional value chains for economic diversification, harnessing the demographic dividend and increasing engagement with young people in the design of policies and programmes.

18.5	In pursuing these strategic directions, ECA will employ its convening function, through the provision of multilateral and multi-stakeholder platforms; its think tank function, by conducting interdisciplinary research and the analysis of key challenges facing its members and Africa as a whole, while promoting peer learning and development; and its operational function, through the provision of tailor-made policy and technical advice to its members, including in cooperation with other entities of the United Nations system. In line with action 45 (a) of the Pact for the Future, ECA will further strengthen its institutional capabilities to better support member States in delivering on its mandates.

18.6	With regard to cooperation with other entities, ECA will continue its close cooperation with the African Union Commission and will build upon its existing strategic partnerships with regional and subregional organizations, central banks, universities, think tanks and civil society and private sector organizations and forge new partnerships towards the fulfilment of the 2030 Agenda and Agenda 2063. Regarding South-South and triangular cooperation, ECA will leverage partnerships premised on the principle of enhancing complementarity and impact.

18.7	With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, ECA will continue to work through the Regional Collaborative Platform for Africa and its opportunity and issue-based coalitions, and will enhance collaboration with regional United Nations entities, the Department of Economic and Social Affairs, the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, resident coordinators and country teams.
18.8	With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:

(a)	Members of ECA and regional economic communities continue to cooperate among and between themselves for harmonized action, focusing on implementation of the 2030 Agenda and Agenda 2063 and operationalization of the African Continental Free Trade Area;

(b)	The Africa Regional Forum for Sustainable Development, the Conference of African Ministers of Finance, Planning and Economic Development, and the subregional intergovernmental committees of experts and senior officials continue to provide policy advice to ECA on emerging priorities.

18.9	The Commission integrates a gender perspective in its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate, by promoting further alignment and coherence between global, regional and national frameworks on gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls. Moreover, subprogramme 6 will continue to provide technical support to the Commission’s other subprogrammes to integrate a gender perspective in their work.

18.10	In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, ECA will pursue the implementation of measures to ensure the inclusion of persons with disabilities, through its programme design, implementation and evaluation, including the provision of reasonable accommodation for conference and workshop participants.

children.text: Evaluation activities
18.13	The following evaluations completed in 2024 have guided the proposed programme plan for 2026:
(a)	Synthesis review of evaluation results for regional economic commissions: contributions to economic development, conducted by the Office of Internal Oversight Services;

(b)	Four project evaluations conducted by ECA in the areas of debt, taxation and financing for development; social protection; the demographic dividend and gender equality; and pooled procurement of essential drugs and local pharmaceutical production through the African Continental Free Trade Area.

18.14	In response to the results of the evaluations referenced above, the Commission will strengthen its collaboration with resident coordinators and United Nations country teams, in a more structured manner, to enhance coherence in the support provided to member States. ECA will also strengthen the monitoring and evaluation of its projects and programmes and integrate lessons learned to improve programming. For instance, in response to the recommendations from the project evaluation on pooled procurement of essential drugs and local pharmaceutical production, a more robust knowledge management system will be developed as part of the next phase of the project.
18.15	The following evaluations to be conducted by ECA are planned for 2026:

(a)	Seven project evaluations on ECA support in the areas of tourism and transport; land governance; public finance; gender statistics; improving data for national public health initiatives; and international migration;
(b)	Evaluation of subprogramme 4, Data and statistics.
Programme of work
Subprogramme 1 – Macroeconomic policy, finance and governance
Objective

18.16	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to achieve structural transformation and inclusive growth in Africa through strengthened and effective development planning, macroeconomic policy analysis, enhanced economic governance and management, and innovative public and private sector financing.
Strategy
18.17	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:
(a)	Provide technical assistance, capacity-building and policy advice to members of ECA on:

(i)	Tracking progress in the implementation of the 2030 Agenda, Agenda 2063 and the Doha Programme of Action for the Least Developed Countries, and designing, implementing and monitoring their national development plans;

(ii)	Designing and implementing policy frameworks that promote transparency and accountability in public financial management, including debt management, and resource mobilization and allocation to build resilience to shocks;
(iii)	Identifying priority growth sectors and promoting the development and implementation of initiatives to improve their competitiveness, attract investment and stimulate entrepreneurship;

(iv)	Developing and deepening their domestic capital markets and developing innovative and sustainable financing solutions for mobilizing additional resources to meet development financing needs and increase financial resilience;

(b)	Convene platforms for policy dialogue on matters related to macroeconomic policy, economic governance, financing and development planning, including the annual session of the Conference of African Ministers of Finance, Planning and Economic Development;

(c)	Publish policy-relevant knowledge products underpinned by research and macroeconomic modelling tools and produce, upon request, forecasts with recommendations for responding to the impacts of external shocks.
18.18	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	More coordinated and integrated policy design and implementation by members of ECA;
(b)	Accelerated and sustainable graduation of African countries from the least developed country category;
(c)	Increased mobilization of resources and capital for development and investment in priority areas;
(d)	Improved debt management and reduced debt vulnerabilities among members of ECA;
(e)	An enabling environment that allows for improved access to markets and a diversified investor base with an increased appetite for domestic currency debt markets.
Programme performance in 2024
A common African position on financing for development

18.19	Africa faces significant gaps in development financing, which hinders progress towards the 2030 Agenda and Agenda 2063. Millions of people still lack access to essential services, such as education, healthcare and infrastructure. Bridging these financing gaps is critical to unlocking the full potential of Africa and to accelerating development and achieving inclusive and sustainable growth for the continent. The International Conference on Financing for Development offers a vital opportunity for African nations to influence financing frameworks to better address their unique challenges. To leverage this platform effectively, it is essential for African countries to establish a common position and agree on priority areas. To this end, the subprogramme, in collaboration with the African Union Commission, the African Tax Administration Forum, the African Development Bank, the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development and the Department of Economic and Social Affairs, conducted regional consultations on financing for development. The consultations facilitated exchange of experience and contributed to the identification of priority actions, including in the areas of domestic resource mobilization, international trade, debt sustainability and addressing systemic challenges to financing for development.

children.text: Result 3: enhanced macroeconomic forecasting and development planning for inclusive and sustainable growth – Proposed programme plan for 2026

18.25	Utilization of robust macroeconomic models is a critical foundation for macroeconomic management and effective development planning. The subprogramme has supported members of ECA in the development of tailored macroeconomic analysis while also providing technical assistance and policy advice for the development of national development plans. The subprogramme also utilizes a comprehensive macroeconomic analysis tool and an integrated planning and reporting toolkit to build the capacity of member States to generate accurate macroeconomic forecasts and integrate global and regional priorities into national plans.
Lessons learned and planned change

18.26	The lessons for the subprogramme were the importance of effective macroeconomic analysis that uses reliable data to ensure accurate macroeconomic forecasting and reporting in the development and implementation of national development plans and the need to further strengthen the capacities of member States to apply economic policy analysis in the formulation of their national development plans. In applying the lessons, the subprogramme will support member States in engaging in more accurate macroeconomic forecasting, in order to plan and monitor national development plans, and ensure their alignment with international commitments.
18.27	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.II).
Figure 18.II

children.text: Subprogramme 2 – Regional integration and trade
Objective

18.29	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to strengthen regional cooperation and integration among members of ECA through increased trade flows, improved industrialization and increased investment.
Strategy
18.30	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Provide advisory services and technical assistance to members of ECA on market access and business opportunities arising from the African Continental Free Trade Area to minimize potential adverse effects (such as import surges, dumping and customs revenue loss risks) in the context of the implementation of their national strategies, and multilateral and bilateral trade issues;

(b)	Develop and disseminate knowledge products and provide technical assistance to identify opportunities for diversification, value addition and the development of manufacturing and industrial clusters for members of ECA in support of the Action Plan for the Accelerated Industrial Development of Africa, contributing to the achievement of Sustainable Development Goals 9 and 17;

(c)	Provide training, with a particular focus on least developed countries, landlocked developing countries and regional economic communities, on the implementation of existing regional cooperation frameworks;

(d)	Provide advisory services and technical assistance to members of ECA and regional economic communities on regional integration, national, regional and continental competition policies, intellectual property policies and measures for investment facilitation.
18.31	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Improved implementation by countries of their respective strategies for the operationalization of the African Continental Free Trade Area;
(b)	More coherent, coordinated and responsive interfaces between the African Continental Free Trade Area and the free trade areas and customs unions of the regional economic communities;
(c)	More coherent trade and industrialization policies aligned with the 2030 Agenda and Agenda 2063;
(d)	Accelerated industrialization and increased diversification of productive capacities and production patterns;
(e)	Reduced transaction risks and intermediation costs for members of ECA;

(f)	An improved business environment characterized by enhanced opportunities for private sector operators to leverage transboundary opportunities and improved market access conditions for African trade of goods and services, as well as the free movement of capital and people.
Programme performance in 2024
Members of ECA improved readiness for continental trade integration

18.32	National strategies for the implementation of the African Continental Free Trade Area help to identify priority products or services in each African country with high export potential to other African markets and to define concrete steps to achieve such exports. These strategies also outline risks and opportunities for integration into regional and global value chains, as well as vulnerable sectors and products that may require special consideration and support measures. The subprogramme has provided extensive support to members of ECA in formulating national strategies for implementation of the African Continental Free Trade Area, including through facilitation of multi-stakeholder consultations, policy advice on alignment with national development plans and technical assistance to conduct rigorous assessment of trade competitiveness and regulatory constraints. In 2024, building on work undertaken in previous years, the subprogramme supported Equatorial Guinea, Eswatini, Liberia and Morocco in the finalization and validation of their national implementation strategies; it also supported the Arab Maghreb Union in the development of a subregional strategy on trade integration. The strategy of Equatorial Guinea was designed to leverage the country’s energy resources to expand intra-African trade and attract investment in downstream industries. The strategy of Eswatini targeted export diversification through enhanced trade facilitation and digital trade systems, whereas the strategy of Liberia emphasized trade infrastructure upgrades and the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises. The strategy of Morocco prioritized strengthening industrial and agroprocessing value chains to capitalize on the country’s export potential, while the plan of the Arab Maghreb Union was focused on the reduction of non-tariff barriers and the harmonization of customs procedures among its member States. These strategies mark a critical step towards realizing the objectives of the African Continental Free Trade Area, supporting industrialization, job creation and sustainable development across the continent.
18.33	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.III).
Figure 18.III
Performance measure: number of countries that finalized and validated national strategies for the implementation of the African Continental Free Trade Area (cumulative)
Planned results for 2026

Result 1: members of ECA implement priority areas of their strategies for the implementation of the Agreement Establishing the African Continental Free Trade Area related to industrialization – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

18.34	The subprogramme’s work contributed to the implementation by five additional members of ECA of the priority areas of their national strategies for the implementation of the Agreement Establishing the African Continental Free Trade Area, for a total of 13, which exceeded the planned target of 10 members of ECA.
18.35	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.IV).
Figure 18.IV

Performance measure: number of members of ECA implementing the priority areas of their national strategies for the implementation of the Agreement Establishing the African Continental Free Trade Area related to industrialization (cumulative)
Result 2: sustainable trade strategies to mitigate the impact of climate change – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

18.36	The subprogramme’s work contributed to the adoption by an additional 10 countries of sustainable trade strategies that include considerations related to climate change, for a total of 15 countries, which met the planned target.
18.37	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.V).
Figure 18.V
Performance measure: number of members of ECA adopting sustainable trade strategies that include considerations related to climate change (cumulative)
Result 3: members of ECA adopt measures to de-risk investments in regional value chains and special economic zones – Proposed programme plan for 2026

18.38	The number of special economic zones on the African continent has expanded considerably in the past three decades, to approximately 240. These zones contributed to increased foreign direct investment inflows during their initial operation, but sustaining that level of inflows has proved challenging, owing to, in part, a focus on extractive industries, limited diversification and restriction of investment within national boundaries. In response, new special economic zones have been identified, with the aim of fostering horizontal and vertical linkages in supply chains, capitalizing on cross-border complementarities, and promoting local and regional sourcing, and which are aligned closely with national and regional development goals.
Lessons learned and planned change

18.39	The lessons for the subprogramme were the need to foster greater regional collaboration in the development and operation of special economic zones and the establishment of regional value chains and the need to provide greater support to member States in de-risking investments, including through diversification. In applying the lessons, the subprogramme will facilitate increased communication and cooperation among member States to promote the development of cross-border special economic zones; it will also develop knowledge products and provide capacity-building support on diversification with a view to expanding such zones beyond the extractive industries. Furthermore, the subprogramme will facilitate policy dialogues involving member States and investors on the de-risking of investments and on solutions to address potential investor concerns.
18.40	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.VI).
Figure 18.VI
Performance measure: number of ECA member States adopting measures to de-risk investments in regional value chains and special economic zones (annual)

children.text: Subprogramme 3 – Technology, innovation, connectivity and infrastructure development
Objective

18.42	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to advance inclusive growth, sustainable development and economic transformation in Africa through science, technology and innovation, improved connectivity, logistics and infrastructure development.
Strategy
18.43	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:
(a)	Conduct policy research and analysis on:
(i)	Digital trends on the continent, including those related to the economic impact of new and emerging technologies and technology-driven solutions for sustainable development;

(ii)	The state of energy, transport and information and communications technology infrastructure at the national and regional levels and the impact of logistics and connectivity on economic development;
(b)	Provide technical assistance and advisory services to members of ECA, the African Union and its bodies, and subregional organizations on:

(i)	The design and implementation of regulatory frameworks that promote digital public infrastructure, digital systems and policies related to technology and innovation, including principles for good digital identification, data governance, information and communications technology security, financial technology and responsible use of artificial intelligence;
(ii)	The design and implementation of policies and strategies to bridge technological and innovation gaps and promote digital inclusivity and digital connectivity across the continent;

(iii)	The development of an academic and entrepreneurial ecosystem for science, technology and innovation through partnerships and capacity-building initiatives with a view to developing a critical mass of researchers, experts and innovators for evidence-based decision-making and innovation-driven growth in member States;
(iv)	The implementation of the Programme for Infrastructure Development in Africa and the design of regulatory frameworks to enhance private sector investment in infrastructure while managing risk;

(v)	The development of transport infrastructure and services, including transport facilitation, norms and standards, regulations, road safety and asset management, with a particular focus on the liberalization of intra-African air transport in the context of the Single African Air Transport Market and the digitalization of transport infrastructure;
(vi)	The development of infrastructure to improve energy access, advance market development and foster the transition to renewable sources of energy.
18.44	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	Improved digital ecosystems across the continent, enabling the implementation of better policy and regulatory frameworks that enhance the use of digital public infrastructure, innovation and digital systems;

(b)	Strengthened and enhanced digital inclusivity and connectivity in members of ECA and across the continent, through effective policies and strategies, reducing technological disparities and ensuring broader access to digital resources and innovations;

(c)	A strengthened science, technology and innovation ecosystem with a greater number of capacity-building initiatives, leading to a critical mass of researchers, experts and innovators driving evidence-based decision-making and innovation-driven growth;
(d)	Increased efficiency and safety of the African transport sector;
(e)	Increased energy access and innovative financing for energy infrastructure;
(f)	Increased private sector investment in new and emerging technologies and public infrastructure.
18.45	In doing so, the subprogramme will support members of ECA in making progress towards Sustainable Development Goals 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 13 and 17.
Programme performance in 2024
Member States committed to actions to achieve a people-centred, inclusive and development-oriented information society

18.46	The goal of the World Summit on the Information Society is the establishment of a people-centred, inclusive and development-oriented information society. With 2025 marking 20 years since its inception, and in accordance with General Assembly resolution 70/125, the subprogramme provided support to members of ECA in the regional review of the overall implementation of the outcomes of the Summit. In 2024, the subprogramme, in collaboration with the Government of the United Republic of Tanzania, convened a review workshop in Dar es Salaam, United Republic of Tanzania, to evaluate the progress made in Africa over nearly two decades. Some 150 stakeholders representing 37 member States participated. Member States assessed achievements and identified gaps, with a focus on national-level implementation of the Summit’s action lines. They also established new priorities for the digital future of Africa. A significant outcome of the workshop was the adoption of a declaration on the regional review process. In that declaration, member States highlighted, among other points, the need to prioritize capacity-building, education and digital skills development to unlock the potential of artificial intelligence and digital public infrastructure; digitalize government services; promote entrepreneurship, in particular for women, young people and persons with disabilities; and harmonize legal and policy frameworks to support cross-border data-sharing and e-commerce. In addition, member States were called upon to adopt, with the support of ECA, the African Union and regional economic communities, multi-stakeholder processes to fast-track the implementation of nine key initiatives identified in the declaration.
18.47	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 18.6).
Table 18.6
Performance measure

children.text: Result 2: members of ECA leverage technology and innovation to manage their transport and energy infrastructure – Proposed programme plan for 2026

18.50	Harnessing the natural resources of Africa through technology can provide a pathway for the transition to renewable sources of energy. The use of innovative technology solutions for energy storage and management can help to address intermittency issues associated with solar and wind power, ensuring a consistent and reliable energy supply. Similarly, innovative technology solutions in the transport sector can help to address such challenges as limited access to affordable and reliable transport, traffic congestion and pollution, paving the way towards more sustainable transportation systems. The subprogramme has supported member States in this regard, including through the development of a methodology for using satellite imagery and artificial intelligence to monitor transport corridors, as well as through the development of software for assessing regulatory openness, attractiveness and readiness for private investment in the electricity value chain.
Lessons learned and planned change

18.51	The lesson for the subprogramme was the need to provide targeted technical assistance to facilitate the adoption of technology solutions to upgrade energy and transport infrastructure. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will provide technical assistance with regard to applying technology platforms to improve the management of transport and energy assets of member States and their institutions. The subprogramme will also provide capacity-building support to enable regional and national institutions to leverage innovation in policies, actions and measures aimed at improving access to energy and strengthening transport systems.

children.text: Subprogramme 4 – Data and statistics
Objective

18.54	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to strengthen the production, dissemination and use of credible data, statistics and geospatial information at the national, regional and global levels for evidence-based policy and decision-making.
Strategy
18.55	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Support African national statistical systems in transforming their data governance and management methods by digitalizing the data collection, compilation and dissemination process for statistical areas, including censuses and civil registration systems, and provide technical assistance and training in the design and implementation of national strategies for the development of statistics and national spatial data infrastructure with related integrated geospatial information frameworks;

(b)	Maintain and regularly update databases that are accessible for public use, with available harmonized data, statistics and geospatial information disaggregated by location on such topics as African economies, demographics, social indicators, the environment and other statistics needed for monitoring and reporting on the implementation of the 2030 Agenda and Agenda 2063;
(c)	Provide training and make platforms available for the exchange of best practices among members of ECA and their respective statistical agencies;

(d)	Integrate policy advice and sustained capacity-building activities on data, statistics and geospatial information to support members of ECA in enhancing monitoring and reporting on the implementation of the 2030 Agenda and Agenda 2063;
(e)	Enhance communication and advocacy to members of ECA on the use of statistics and geospatial information.
18.56	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	Improved capacity, resilience and efficiency of national statistical systems, including the uptake of innovative tools and technologies to collect comparable statistics at various levels of disaggregation, and improved statistical operations, including the conduct of censuses and surveys and administrative data processing and analysis, and dissemination of timely data;

(b)	Improved uptake of geospatial information management, closer collaboration between components and stakeholders of the national spatial data infrastructures, and better integrated geospatial information frameworks;
(c)	Enhanced monitoring and reporting on the implementation of the 2030 Agenda and Agenda 2063.
Programme performance in 2024
Strengthened monitoring of the Sustainable Development Goals and improved dissemination of data

18.57	Monitoring and reporting on the Sustainable Development Goals are crucial for identifying progress and challenges and provide the insights needed to inform evidence-based decision-making on policies and the allocation of resources. Moreover, researchers, academia, civil society and development partners also rely on good-quality and relevant data on the Goals. The subprogramme has assisted requesting member States in developing national reporting platforms for the Goals using Open SDG, an open source platform that enables the creation of an online website for disseminating data on the Goals. The website can be multilingual and is designed with users and accessibility in mind. Disaggregated data and metadata can be reported in a variety of formats, and can be downloaded as tables, charts and maps. Other frameworks, such as national development plans, can also be reported on, using the same functionalities. Such platforms also enable the harmonization and standardization of monitoring and reporting on progress made, enabling more accurate and comparable assessments of regional and global progress. In 2024, the subprogramme organized policy dialogues on monitoring and reporting on the Goals, including statistical concepts and data sources, and provided technical assistance and capacity-building to 10 member States in establishing Open SDG as a national reporting platform. As a result of this support, six member States established Open SDG platforms and have standardized monitoring and reporting on the Goals.
18.58	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.VII).
Figure 18.VII
Performance measure: number of members of ECA that have established a standardized national reporting platform on the Sustainable Development Goals (annual)
Planned results for 2026
Result 1: members of ECA produce and disseminate comparable economic statistics – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

18.59	The subprogramme’s work contributed to the adoption and application by five additional members of ECA of the recommended international standards and methodology in economic statistics, for a cumulative total of 42 members of ECA, which met the planned target.
18.60	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.VIII).
Figure 18.VIII

Performance measure: number of members of ECA having adopted and applied the recommended international standards and methodology (2008 System of National Accounts and extensions) in economic statistics (cumulative)
Result 2: progress towards integrated statistical and geospatial information frameworks – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

18.61	The subprogramme’s work contributed to two additional members of ECA applying the strategic pathways of the United Nations Integrated Geospatial Information Framework to improve their national statistical frameworks and address challenges in the collection, processing, analysis and dissemination of data, which met the planned target.
18.62	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.IX).
Figure 18.IX
Performance measure: number of members of ECA applying at least one of the strategic pathways of the United Nations Integrated Geospatial Information Framework (cumulative)
Result 3: improved civil registration and vital statistics systems – Proposed programme plan for 2026

18.63	Civil registration and vital statistics systems are crucial for both individuals and Governments, providing legal identity, access to services and valuable data to inform policymaking and national development planning. Civil registration and vital statistics systems across Africa exhibit fragmentation and are constructed according to diverse standards and specifications. This variability complicates the provision of standardized technical assistance for common challenges.
Lessons learned and planned change

18.64	The lesson for the subprogramme was the need to provide tailored support for the harmonization of civil registration and vital statistics systems, and for their digitalization, considering that harmonization and digitalization will increase operational functionality, create efficiencies and improve service delivery by increasing access to digital registration services for populations in remote areas. The experiences of countries such as Rwanda and South Africa, which have developed innovative information technology systems, demonstrate that it is possible to significantly enhance the coverage of civil registration and vital statistics systems through the application of technological innovations and tools. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will provide technical support for the digitalization of civil registration and vital statistics systems, in accordance with the recommendations from the Conference of African Ministers responsible for Civil Registration. In addition, the subprogramme will focus on developing the technical capacity of national officials to manage and sustain the use of these systems. The subprogramme will also develop a standardized digital asset that can be referenced and adopted across countries, to better align civil registration and vital statistics systems across the continent.
18.65	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.X).
Figure 18.X
Performance measure: number of members of ECA adopting innovative technology applications in civil registration and vital statistics systems (cumulative)

children.text: Subprogramme 5 – Climate change, food security and natural resources
Objective

18.67	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to enhance climate resilience, achieve food security, and advance inclusive and sustainable development by harnessing land, natural resources, and the green and blue economies.
Strategy
18.68	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:
(a)	Conduct policy research and analysis, and provide technical assistance and advisory services to members of ECA on:

(i)	Extractives-led production linkages and the design and implementation of mineral policies, strategies and plans that consider economic, environmental and social aspects and matters related to gender equality, in line with the principles of the Africa Mining Vision;

(ii)	The circular economy, the development of the green economy in the context of sustainable development and poverty eradication, including the conduct of voluntary national and local reviews, and the blue economy, in line with the Africa Blue Economy Strategy of the African Union;
(iii)	Climate resilience and disaster vulnerability of African economies, societies, ecosystems and agrifood systems and the integrated implementation of climate action;
(iv)	Modelling of the economic impacts of climate change and private sector investments for the implementation of nationally determined contributions;

(v)	Land governance, including policy and regulatory reforms for land tenure security, in particular for women and young people, and the use of the Framework and Guidelines on Land Policy in Africa and geographic information system-based tools to support decision-making regarding responsible land-based investments by the private sector;

(vi)	Agriculture and food systems transformation, through financing, insurance and de-risking investment, youth and women entrepreneurship in agriculture, regional value chains, common agro-parks and agro-industrialization;

(b)	Provide technical advice to the African Union Commission, regional economic communities and intergovernmental organizations on sustainable development planning and policy formulation in the context of the second 10-year implementation plan of Agenda 2063;
(c)	Convene peer-learning policy dialogues and regional consensus-building platforms and support African universities and research institutions in knowledge generation in the above-mentioned areas.
18.69	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Sustainable and diversified economies in African countries rich in natural resources;
(b)	Development of policies, strategies and plans in agriculture and natural resource sectors to enable the transition to environmentally sustainable and climate-resilient economies;
(c)	Improved competitiveness, productivity, value addition and trade in agricultural goods and services;
(d)	Resilient, inclusive and nutrition-oriented food systems;
(e)	Inclusive land-based investments in agriculture and other natural resource sectors, in accordance with the African Union guiding principles for large-scale land-based investments in Africa;
(f)	Improved land tenure security, in accordance with the African Union framework and guidelines on land policy in Africa.
Programme performance in 2024
Strengthened regional capacity for utilization of article 6 of the Paris Agreement

18.70	Article 6 of the Paris Agreement sets out how countries can pursue voluntary cooperation to reach their climate targets. It enables international cooperation to address climate change and can unlock financial support for developing countries. Article 6 establishes a mechanism to contribute to the mitigation of greenhouse gas emissions and support sustainable development, while also enabling non-market approaches to assist in the implementation of nationally determined contributions. In 2023, the subprogramme partnered with the African Group of Negotiators to strengthen regional capacity to utilize article 6, including through various training and awareness-raising events. In 2024, the subprogramme provided capacity-building support on policies and regulatory frameworks linked to article 6 to national United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change focal points and regional experts.
18.71	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XI).
Figure 18.XI
Performance measure: number of national and regional officials with strengthened capacity to utilize article 6 of the Paris Agreement (cumulative)
Planned results for 2026
Result 1: members of ECA develop and implement national and regional policy and cooperation frameworks for the sustainable use of natural resources – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026
18.72	The subprogramme’s work contributed to the adoption of four policy frameworks by members of ECA for the sustainable use of natural resources, which met the planned target.
18.73	Progress toward the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XII).
Figure 18.XII
Performance measure: number of policy frameworks adopted by members of ECA for the sustainable use of natural resources (cumulative)
Result 2: resilient and inclusive agrifood systems – Proposed programme plan for 2026

18.74	The ability of Africa to address food insecurity is hampered by insecure land rights, land degradation and low use of agricultural inputs, technologies, mechanization and practices that increase productivity and build resilience to climate and disaster risks. The subprogramme has engaged in advocacy, developed evidence and tools and strengthened the capacities of member States to develop policies, strategies and programmes to promote value chains, agro-parks, land rights and investments, gender equality, youth entrepreneurship and agricultural insurance.
Lessons learned and planned change

18.75	The lesson for the subprogramme was the importance of fostering synergies and coherence in policy development and implementation. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will establish platforms for greater collaboration among national and regional authorities, as well as with the private sector, civil society and academia, to enable more collaborative approaches to policy development and implementation. The subprogramme will also provide support to enable meaningful integration of its guidelines and tools into strategies, policies and programmes, with a particular focus on agricultural value chains, agro-parks, land governance and management, and the resilience of food systems to climate and other shocks.
18.76	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 18.11).

children.text: Subprogramme 6 – Gender equality and women’s empowerment
Objective

18.78	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to achieve gender equality and women’s empowerment in Africa, by accelerating the pace of implementation by members of ECA and their reporting on their global and regional commitments related to gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls and to enhance their implementation of policies and programmes for the empowerment of women and girls.
Strategy
18.79	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:
(a)	Undertake policy research, provide technical advice, and build capacity on issues relating to gender equality and women’s empowerment;

(b)	Promote women’s economic empowerment, placing particular emphasis on financial inclusion and focusing on the development and implementation of the financial regulatory frameworks of members of ECA;

(c)	Provide technical support to members of ECA, including national machineries for gender equality and line ministries, on integrating a gender perspective into their sectoral development policies and programmes;

(d)	Roll out the African Gender and Development Index and the Africa Gender Index, in collaboration with partners, in the remaining countries that have not yet implemented them, and provide technical support to members of ECA in measuring progress and reporting on the status of implementation of global and regional commitments on gender equality.
18.80	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Strengthened integration of a gender perspective into planning, budgeting, financing and implementation of national policies and programmes;

(b)	Improved understanding of and response by policymakers to global and regional frameworks on gender equality and women’s empowerment, for the alignment of national development outcomes and the fulfilment of national commitments;

(c)	Increased opportunities, greater economic empowerment and improved livelihoods for women and girls across Africa, through smart policies and tools designed to address existing and emerging discrepancies in gender equality;
(d)	Enhanced financial access and opportunities for women by strengthening the financial regulatory frameworks to promote their economic empowerment.
Programme performance in 2024
Members of ECA take stock of progress made in achieving gender equality and women’s empowerment

18.81	Pursuant to resolution 2022/5 of the Economic and Social Council, African member States undertook a regional review in 2024 of the achievements made in implementing the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action. The review assessed progress, identified challenges, highlighted achievements and outlined strategies for the full realization of gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls. The subprogramme contributed to the national-level review reports and facilitated the adoption of a common African position on the status of women related to the review. This was achieved through the provision of technical and advisory support to assist ECA members in conducting comprehensive national-level reviews and in preparing the regional report, which synthesized insights from 42 national review reports and survey data. The report highlighted key achievements over the past five years and prioritized actions to accelerate the implementation of the Beijing Declaration. The subprogramme also convened a ministerial conference on the Africa regional review. As a result, a common African position on the review was adopted by ministers of member States of the African Union in charge of gender and women’s affairs. This common position informed the global report that was considered at the sixty-ninth session of the Commission on the Status of Women in March 2025.

children.text: Result 3: members of ECA take action to improve the financial inclusion of women – Proposed programme plan for 2026

18.87	According to the 30-year review of the implementation of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action and the 2023 Africa Gender Index report, women in Africa continue to face structural and systemic barriers that limit their involvement in formal labour markets and restrict their access to finance and credit. The subprogramme supports member States in improving financial access and opportunities for women. For example, in 2024, the subprogramme held a workshop on financial inclusion for businesswomen that increased their awareness of and provided practical guidance on accessing financial services. The subprogramme has also engaged in advocacy with 34 members of ECA to promote the economic and financial inclusion of women and youth.
Lessons learned and planned change

18.88	The lesson for the subprogramme was that strategic and targeted efforts are required to better understand the challenges concerning and barriers to ensuring women’s financial inclusion. Despite legal reforms, disparities between men and women in financial access persist. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will provide support to member States to conduct research and analysis in order to gain a deeper understanding of key constraints. On the basis of the findings, the subprogramme will develop practical solutions and convene high-level policy dialogues, and provide technical and advisory services to members of ECA to enable them to enhance the financial inclusion of women.

children.text: Subprogramme 7 – Subregional activities for development
Component 1 – Subregional activities in North Africa – Objective

18.91	The objective, to which this component contributes, is to advance inclusive growth and sustainable development in North Africa through strengthened economic diversification, fiscal management, regional integration and a better recognition of migrant workers’ economic contributions.
Strategy
18.92	To contribute to the objective, the component will:
(a)	Develop evidence-based policies, strategies and reforms and provide technical assistance related to economic diversification, fiscal management and resilient and inclusive economies;

(b)	Provide advisory services and hold subregional consultations on the mobilization of domestic resources and the implementation of the Agreement Establishing the African Continental Free Trade Area, in partnership with ministries of trade and the African Union;

(c)	Provide technical assistance and training for selected African countries on migration data collection and analysis and evidence-based policy formulation to mainstream and leverage migrants’ economic contributions, through data collection and analysis;

(d)	Conduct research on challenges facing middle-income countries in North Africa, in particular those relating to development and climate finance, human capital and employment creation in North Africa, with a focus on strategic areas such as digitalization and the green economy in the context of sustainable development and poverty eradication.
18.93	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	Adoption of evidence-based macroeconomic policies and structural reforms by members of ECA to improve fiscal space and enhance productive employment, redirecting resource allocations towards sectors that have a high potential for inclusive and sustainable development;
(b)	Policies and strategies that foster regional integration, enhance productivity and create new jobs in higher-skilled and sustainable sectors;
(c)	Development of evidence-based policies and actions by members of ECA that leverage the contributions of migrants to sustainable development.
18.105	To contribute to the objective, the component will:

(a)	Provide knowledge, tools and policy recommendations on the acceleration of a demographic transition and related implications for sustainable development and climate resilience, including population dynamics, migration, health and mortality, ageing and living conditions, gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls, youth, and sustainable peace and resilience in West Africa, among others;

(b)	Engage in high-level policy dialogues and provide technical support and capacity-strengthening to countries on regional integration issues, including the implementation of the Agreement Establishing the African Continental Free Trade Area, development planning, and the development of budgeting frameworks that are sensitive to a demographic dividend with special emphasis on the empowerment of women and young people.
18.106	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Demographic dividend dimensions mainstreamed in national planning, programming and budgeting processes;
(b)	Deepened regional economic and monetary integration through the operationalization of Vision 2050 of the Economic Community of West African States;
(c)	Accelerated implementation of the 2030 Agenda and Agenda 2063 by member States of ECA and regional organizations, including enhanced capacities in development planning;
(d)	Accelerated implementation of the Agreement Establishing the African Continental Free Trade Area in Africa, with women and young people empowered to seize the opportunities of the Agreement.
18.118	To contribute to the objective, the component will:
(a)	Provide technical assistance and advisory services to members and regional economic communities of ECA in Central Africa on:

(i)	Formulating and implementing national and subregional development plans and economic diversification strategies with a focus on intra-Central African trade and creating a business climate conducive to employment creation and resilient to external shocks;

(ii)	Translating their national strategies for the implementation of the Agreement Establishing the African Continental Free Trade Area into specific and bankable projects, using market access information and trade opportunity data, with a particular focus on the agricultural, energy and pharmaceutical sectors;
(iii)	Transforming transport corridors into development corridors, in line with the Central Africa consensual transport plan;

(iv)	Developing information and communications technology infrastructure and regulatory frameworks required for the digital transition, including support for the establishment of technology innovation centres, in collaboration with the ECA Centre of Excellence on Digital Identity, Trade and Economy within subprogramme 3;

(v)	Harmonizing trade instruments of the Economic Community of Central African States and the Central African Economic and Monetary Community (CEMAC) while developing a unified master plan for industrial development and economic diversification in Central Africa;
(b)	Collaborate with the private sector, subregional think tanks and regional economic communities in the above-mentioned areas;
(c)	Train members of ECA and United Nations country teams in the use of the ECA integrated planning and reporting toolkit.
18.119	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Strengthened regional value chains and industrial clusters, integrated with local economies, and expanded manufacturing and high-value service sectors;

(b)	Integration of the relevant economic diversification-related goals and targets of the 2030 Agenda and Agenda 2063 into national development strategies and plans, common country assessments and United Nations sustainable development cooperation frameworks;
(c)	Increased productivity of local firms and economies, including adoption of new technologies;
(d)	Strengthened role of the private sector in economic diversification in Central Africa.
18.131	To contribute to the objective, the component will:

(a)	Provide support to countries and regional economic communities, through knowledge production, technical assistance, capacity-building and policy dialogues, on the development and effective implementation of their national and regional strategies for the implementation of the Agreement Establishing the African Continental Free Trade Area African Continental Free Trade Area, and the negotiation and arrangements concerning outstanding protocols and instruments on the Area;

(b)	Foster the development of regional value chains in food and agriculture through value chain analyses and the dissemination of information to public and private sector stakeholders about investment opportunities;

(c)	Build the capacity of the private sector to take part in operationalizing the African Continental Free Trade Area, through information and awareness-raising workshops on the functionalities of the instruments and protocols;

(d)	Engage in policy dialogue and provide training to promote transboundary investments and cost-effective trade logistics, including the creation and use of digital platforms and commodity exchanges to reduce asymmetries of information;

(e)	Convene a subregional forum on issues related to the blue economy, including its potential to diversify goods and services and to operationalize the African Continental Free Trade Area, assess the socioeconomic potential of the blue economy and conduct market analyses for small and medium-sized enterprises, while keeping in mind the need to protect natural resources;

(f)	Support members of ECA in the development of national tourism strategies, in line with the recommendations set out in the African tourism strategy and provide training on the production of high-quality tourism statistics in the subregion.
18.132	The above-mentioned work will help members of ECA to make progress towards the achievement of Sustainable Development Goals 5, 7, 8, 11, 12, 13, 14 and 17.
18.133	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	National development planning frameworks incorporating and amplifying blue economy policies and strategies;
(b)	Standardized methodologies for tourism data collection and analysis in the subregion;
(c)	Increased market diversification and economic resilience to external shocks, related in particular to the blue economy, the tourism sector and food-related value chains;
(d)	Deeper regional integration and improved connectivity of landlocked countries;
(e)	Higher levels of intraregional trade in goods and services;
(f)	Harmonization of investment regimes and investment promotion strategies, and improved regulatory frameworks governing investment.
18.145	To contribute to the objective, the component will:

(a)	Undertake policy research and analysis on inclusive and sustainable industrialization, regional integration and trade, private sector development, and poverty and inequality, provide technical assistance to members of ECA, regional economic communities and intergovernmental organizations and disseminate best practices at the subregional and national levels in Southern Africa;

(b)	Develop and disseminate policy tools and guidelines for the promotion of inclusive and sustainable industrialization, including value addition, manufacturing and value chain development, at the national and subregional levels in Southern Africa;

(c)	Support members of ECA in the implementation of Vision 2050 of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) and its regional indicative strategic development plan for 2020–2030, thereby contributing to the achievement of Sustainable Development Goals 1, 8, 9 and 10 and related goals of Agenda 2063;

(d)	Collaborate with partners, including the African Union Southern Africa Regional Office, SADC, the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA), the African Development Bank, the African Export-Import Bank, private sector associations and research institutions:

(i)	To strengthen the capacities of members of ECA to advance inclusive and sustainable industrialization and regional integration through implementation of the SADC industrialization strategy and road map (2015–2063), the SADC Regional Energy Access Strategy and Action Plan (2020–2030), the COMESA industrial policy (2015–2030), the African Continental Free Trade Area and the free trade areas of the regional economic communities;

(ii)	To provide technical support for the development of strategies and guidelines for the integration of considerations related to climate change into industrialization and trade policies in Southern Africa;
(e)	Build the capacities of members of ECA and the private sector:

(i)	To address the challenges and opportunities of the green economy in the context of sustainable development and poverty eradication, and to increase productive capacities, in particular, given the situation of energy resource deficiency in the region and the impact of climate change on key sectors;
(ii)	To address the impact of external shocks, by rolling out initiatives aimed at supporting their recovery and strengthening their resilience to future shocks;
(iii)	To leverage digitalization, science, technology and innovation to facilitate growth, business development and enhanced productivity and competitiveness.
18.146	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Enhanced implementation of the SADC Vision 2050 and indicative strategic plan, the SADC industrialization strategy and road map and the COMESA industrial policy;

(b)	Economic diversification and transformation through value addition and the development of sustainable regional value chains, accelerated by transboundary industrial clusters, hubs and special economic zones in selected members of ECA;
(c)	Harmonization of national industrial policies with regional industrial frameworks and integration of considerations related to the environment and sustainability;

(d)	Accelerated implementation of the Agreement Establishing the African Continental Free Trade Area and the free trade agreements of the regional economic communities, increased intraregional trade in goods and services and enhanced regional integration in Southern Africa;
(e)	Increased resilience and competitiveness of the private sector and micro, small and medium-sized enterprises and enhanced participation in industry and trade in Southern Africa;
(f)	Evidence-based policy responses related to poverty, inequality and vulnerability situations in Southern Africa through informed analyses of trends and causal factors.
Programme performance in 2024
Member States adopt the Rabat Declaration on Middle-Income Countries

18.94	Addressing the needs and specific challenges of middle-income countries is critical for the achievement of the 2030 Agenda. Having attained middle-income status, many middle-income countries in North Africa have found it difficult to sustain the dynamism of their economic development and their progress in increasing incomes. This is often associated with growing difficulties in sustaining levels and types of investment that can generate continued improvements in their productivity and adequate employment growth. In 2024, the component, in collaboration with the Government of Morocco and the United Nations Development Programme, organized a high-level ministerial conference that brought together 32 countries, 23 United Nations development agencies and other international and regional institutions to discuss solutions to address the development challenges faced by middle-income countries, including financing gaps. The conference led to the adoption of the Rabat Declaration, which contains a set of action-oriented and innovative solutions and stresses the importance of South-South cooperation and triangular cooperation in addressing the development needs of middle-income countries. The Declaration also included a commitment to develop a strategic action plan for middle-income countries covering the period 2025–2030, in collaboration with the United Nations system and other stakeholders.

children.text: Members of ECA integrate the demographic dividend into national budgeting processes

18.107	The West Africa demographic profile offers a vital demographic dividend opportunity that could be more effectively harnessed through the strategic allocation of resources. In 2024, the component continued to strengthen national capacities in budgeting sensitive to the demographic dividend and engaged policymakers from line ministries (e.g. budget, planning, employment, education and health) and members of parliament on applying approaches sensitive to the demographic dividend in their national budgeting processes. This work was undertaken with a view to supporting member States in ensuring that their 2025 national budgets reflect sensitivity to the demographic dividend. As a result of these efforts, three countries (Burkina Faso, Niger and Togo) integrated demographic dividend-related issues into their 2025 budgetary programming documents, laying the foundation for its integration in the 2025 national budgets of those countries.
18.108	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XV).
Figure 18.XV
Performance measure: number of countries that integrated the demographic dividend into their budgetary planning and programming documents (cumulative)
Members of ECA implement projects for improved industrialization and economic diversification

18.120	The year 2024 marked the fourth year of the Decade for Economic Diversification in Central Africa (2021–2030), which has a goal of transitioning subregional economies from commodity dependence to manufacturing and services for sustainable, inclusive and resilient growth. The component supports this shift through a demand-driven programme of research, technical advice, capacity-building, policy support and investment advocacy. In 2022, CEMAC adopted the Master Plan for Industrialization and Economic Diversification. During 2023 and 2024, the component supported member States in the region to operationalize the Master Plan at the national level, including by providing technical advice, hosting communities of practice and supporting the conduct of feasibility studies. As a result of those efforts, four member States (Cameroon, Chad, Congo and Gabon) launched projects in 2024 to implement the Master Plan, covering areas such as wood processing, beef value chain development, industrial fertilizers and the digital economy. In July 2024, the Commission of CEMAC and ECA also signed a memorandum of understanding to strengthen their partnership framework and advance economic diversification in the subregion.

children.text: A new sustainable tourism master plan launched by the Intergovernmental Authority on Development

18.134	Tourism is a significant sector across many economies in East Africa and constitutes a key component of sustainable development. In 2023, the component convened a regional consultative workshop to review lessons learned from the implementation of the Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD) Sustainable Tourism Master Plan (2013–2023) to inform the development of the new master plan. The workshop brought together regional officials from IGAD, national representatives, development partners and stakeholders from the tourism sector to assess progress made and identify gaps to be addressed. This led to the development of a road map to guide the development of the new master plan. Building on the insights from the workshop and through further support provided by the component, IGAD launched the Sustainable Tourism Master Plan 2024–2034, which maps an ambitious path towards enhanced regional cooperation in the area of tourism and strengthening IGAD members’ position in the global tourism market. Building on the success of the previous Sustainable Tourism Master Plan (2013–2023), during which tourism’s contribution to the regional economy rose from 3.8 per cent to 11.4 per cent, the new plan focuses on leveraging IGAD members’ rich cultural heritage, diverse landscapes and unique assets to drive socioeconomic growth. It emphasizes cross-border cooperation, capacity-building, infrastructure development and environmental sustainability, and highlights the need to address issues such as deforestation and marine preservation.

children.text: Advanced integrated development planning in the Southern African Development Community region through digital solutions

18.147	Cooperation among countries on development planning enhances coherence between global, continental and regional development frameworks and national development plans, while also facilitating the monitoring of progress in achieving the agreed development objectives. The component provided technical support and advisory services to SADC member States towards the design and deployment of an online portal for the SADC National Planning Entities Platform, a forum established to foster cooperation on integrated development planning among the ministries, commissions or agencies responsible for national development planning in the 16 members of SADC. The online portal is a tool with multimedia archiving and retrieval functionality for data- and information-sharing on development priorities and emerging issues of common interest to facilitate cooperation among the national planning entities. Furthermore, the component delivered capacity-building training, through which officials (administrators, planners and other technical users) from SADC member States and officials from the SADC secretariat were equipped with technical knowledge and skills for using the digital tool.

children.text: Result 3: members of ECA accelerate inclusive and sustainable growth through increased productivity, diversification and value addition – Proposed programme plan for 2026

18.100	Six of the seven member States in the North African subregion covered by the component are now classified as middle-income countries. The subregion as a whole is characterized by slow growth and relatively high unemployment rates. To address these challenges, the component has been supporting countries to build and enhance capacities for structural transformation, productivity gains, technology adoption and innovation, and human skills development, and to mobilize adequate and affordable finance and address climate challenges. Accelerating and sustaining inclusive growth and job creation is a priority for all North African countries, as evidenced by their requests for assistance from the component in this regard.
Lessons learned and planned change

18.101	The lesson for the component was that member States needed further support to be able to undertake fundamental policy shifts and actions in order to move from an investment-driven economy to an innovation-driven knowledge economy. In applying the lesson, the component will develop knowledge products, provide advisory services and engage in capacity-building to support the development of national industrial policies. Such policies would guide industrial transformation, diversification and value addition and support the building of human and technological capabilities. The component will also provide support to member States in leveraging private capital for investment in renewable sources of energy and in digitalization.
18.102	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XIV).
Figure 18.XIV
Performance measure: number of policy measures adopted by member States to promote increased productivity, diversification and value addition (cumulative)

Result 1: regional performance monitoring and accountability mechanism to monitor and report on progress in the implementation of the African Union road map on harnessing the demographic dividend through investments in youth – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

18.109	The component’s work contributed to the enhanced capacity of an additional 198 national officials in the use of demo-economics and planning tools, for a cumulative total of 405 national officials, which exceeded the planned target of 237. The component’s work also contributed to a stocktaking survey to inform the development of a regional monitoring and accountability mechanism for the implementation of the African Union road map, which did not meet the planned target of five members of ECA establishing a performance monitoring and accountability mechanism for a demographic dividend. The target was not met due to the need for further analysis and advocacy with members of ECA for its establishment.
18.110	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XVI).
Figure 18.XVI

Performance measure: number of national officials acquiring enhanced capacity in demographic dynamics and policy implications and number of members of ECA establishing a performance monitoring and accountability mechanism for a demographic dividend (cumulative)
Result 2: members of ECA assess debt sustainability and develop longer-term fiscal strategies – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026
18.111	The component’s work contributed to two members of ECA (Ghana and Liberia) developing long-term fiscal strategies to address debt, which met the planned target.
18.112	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XVII).
Figure 18.XVII
Performance measure: number of members of ECA developing longer-term fiscal strategies to address debt (cumulative)
Result 3: increased operationalization of national African Continental Free Trade Area strategies – Proposed programme plan for 2026

18.113	The component has supported member States in the West African region in operationalizing their national African Continental Free Trade Area strategies and has worked to foster cross-regional collaboration in this regard. Key examples of support include capacity-building of over 1,200 stakeholders, including women and youth entrepreneurs as key drivers of economic diversification; development of trade information tools and intra-Africa market access tools; and conducting research and analysis to inform member States in the formulation and implementation of their national African Continental Free Trade Area strategies.
Lessons learned and planned change

18.114	The lesson for the component, based on a pilot project involving eight countries in West and North Africa, was the importance of cross-border and cross-regional collaboration. The pilot project enabled these countries to establish strong and inclusive institutional mechanisms to coordinate and monitor the implementation of the African Continental Free Trade Area. In applying the lesson, the component will prioritize peer-learning initiatives and cross-border exchanges for mutual learning. The component will also support member States in West Africa to mobilize additional resources to accelerate implementation of national African Continental Free Trade Area strategies and enhance the capacities of small and medium-sized enterprises to trade under the African Continental Free Trade Area.
18.115	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XVIII).
Figure 18.XVIII
Performance measure: number of West African countries that have implemented priority areas of their national African Continental Free Trade Area strategies (cumulative)

The target was not met due to the time required to conduct and validate pre-feasibility studies prior to mobilizing financing and initiating implementation.

children.text: Result 3: Central African members of ECA enhance natural asset assessments and capitalization – Proposed programme plan for 2026

18.126	In support of the economic diversification ambitions of Central African members of ECA, the component has actively advocated for greater accounting and capitalization of the subregion’s abundant natural assets. However, investment in natural capital is often stymied by limited data and inadequate assessments, restricting accurate valuations, effective planning and sustainable management. The component supports members of ECA in promoting natural capital accounting in the subregion and in conducting economic impact assessments of natural assets.
Lessons learned and planned change

18.127	The lesson for the component was that sequential capacity-building workshops are more effective at fostering country-level understanding and ownership of quantitative tools than stand-alone knowledge products and publications. This approach is critical, as integrating natural capital accounting can take multiple years and requires high-level commitment. In applying the lesson, the component will implement its newly developed strategy, which is based on five phases: (i) establishing high-level policy commitment; (ii) conducting baseline assessments; (iii) pilot implementation; (iv) developing plans for data integration; and (v) the effective elaboration of economic environmental accounts and revaluation of national wealth. As part of this approach, the component will collaborate with national statistical offices, relevant ministries and other partners to organize training that fully equips officials to independently conduct future analytical updates using natural capital accounting methodologies and tools.
18.128	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 18.XX).
Figure 18.XX
Performance measure: number of countries better equipped to independently apply natural capital accounting methods to conduct economic impact assessment of natural assets (cumulative)
