children.text: Component 4 – Subregional activities in East Africa – Objective

18.130	The objective, to which this component contributes, is to achieve deeper regional integration in East Africa by advancing the operationalization of the African Continental Free Trade Area, increasing intraregional investments, harnessing the blue economy and enhancing regional tourism.
Strategy
18.92	To contribute to the objective, the component will:
(a)	Develop evidence-based policies, strategies and reforms and provide technical assistance related to economic diversification, fiscal management and resilient and inclusive economies;

(b)	Provide advisory services and hold subregional consultations on the mobilization of domestic resources and the implementation of the Agreement Establishing the African Continental Free Trade Area, in partnership with ministries of trade and the African Union;

(c)	Provide technical assistance and training for selected African countries on migration data collection and analysis and evidence-based policy formulation to mainstream and leverage migrants’ economic contributions, through data collection and analysis;

(d)	Conduct research on challenges facing middle-income countries in North Africa, in particular those relating to development and climate finance, human capital and employment creation in North Africa, with a focus on strategic areas such as digitalization and the green economy in the context of sustainable development and poverty eradication.
18.93	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	Adoption of evidence-based macroeconomic policies and structural reforms by members of ECA to improve fiscal space and enhance productive employment, redirecting resource allocations towards sectors that have a high potential for inclusive and sustainable development;
(b)	Policies and strategies that foster regional integration, enhance productivity and create new jobs in higher-skilled and sustainable sectors;
(c)	Development of evidence-based policies and actions by members of ECA that leverage the contributions of migrants to sustainable development.
18.105	To contribute to the objective, the component will:

(a)	Provide knowledge, tools and policy recommendations on the acceleration of a demographic transition and related implications for sustainable development and climate resilience, including population dynamics, migration, health and mortality, ageing and living conditions, gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls, youth, and sustainable peace and resilience in West Africa, among others;

(b)	Engage in high-level policy dialogues and provide technical support and capacity-strengthening to countries on regional integration issues, including the implementation of the Agreement Establishing the African Continental Free Trade Area, development planning, and the development of budgeting frameworks that are sensitive to a demographic dividend with special emphasis on the empowerment of women and young people.
18.106	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Demographic dividend dimensions mainstreamed in national planning, programming and budgeting processes;
(b)	Deepened regional economic and monetary integration through the operationalization of Vision 2050 of the Economic Community of West African States;
(c)	Accelerated implementation of the 2030 Agenda and Agenda 2063 by member States of ECA and regional organizations, including enhanced capacities in development planning;
(d)	Accelerated implementation of the Agreement Establishing the African Continental Free Trade Area in Africa, with women and young people empowered to seize the opportunities of the Agreement.
18.118	To contribute to the objective, the component will:
(a)	Provide technical assistance and advisory services to members and regional economic communities of ECA in Central Africa on:

(i)	Formulating and implementing national and subregional development plans and economic diversification strategies with a focus on intra-Central African trade and creating a business climate conducive to employment creation and resilient to external shocks;

(ii)	Translating their national strategies for the implementation of the Agreement Establishing the African Continental Free Trade Area into specific and bankable projects, using market access information and trade opportunity data, with a particular focus on the agricultural, energy and pharmaceutical sectors;
(iii)	Transforming transport corridors into development corridors, in line with the Central Africa consensual transport plan;

(iv)	Developing information and communications technology infrastructure and regulatory frameworks required for the digital transition, including support for the establishment of technology innovation centres, in collaboration with the ECA Centre of Excellence on Digital Identity, Trade and Economy within subprogramme 3;

(v)	Harmonizing trade instruments of the Economic Community of Central African States and the Central African Economic and Monetary Community (CEMAC) while developing a unified master plan for industrial development and economic diversification in Central Africa;
(b)	Collaborate with the private sector, subregional think tanks and regional economic communities in the above-mentioned areas;
(c)	Train members of ECA and United Nations country teams in the use of the ECA integrated planning and reporting toolkit.
18.119	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Strengthened regional value chains and industrial clusters, integrated with local economies, and expanded manufacturing and high-value service sectors;

(b)	Integration of the relevant economic diversification-related goals and targets of the 2030 Agenda and Agenda 2063 into national development strategies and plans, common country assessments and United Nations sustainable development cooperation frameworks;
(c)	Increased productivity of local firms and economies, including adoption of new technologies;
(d)	Strengthened role of the private sector in economic diversification in Central Africa.
18.131	To contribute to the objective, the component will:

(a)	Provide support to countries and regional economic communities, through knowledge production, technical assistance, capacity-building and policy dialogues, on the development and effective implementation of their national and regional strategies for the implementation of the Agreement Establishing the African Continental Free Trade Area African Continental Free Trade Area, and the negotiation and arrangements concerning outstanding protocols and instruments on the Area;

(b)	Foster the development of regional value chains in food and agriculture through value chain analyses and the dissemination of information to public and private sector stakeholders about investment opportunities;

(c)	Build the capacity of the private sector to take part in operationalizing the African Continental Free Trade Area, through information and awareness-raising workshops on the functionalities of the instruments and protocols;

(d)	Engage in policy dialogue and provide training to promote transboundary investments and cost-effective trade logistics, including the creation and use of digital platforms and commodity exchanges to reduce asymmetries of information;

(e)	Convene a subregional forum on issues related to the blue economy, including its potential to diversify goods and services and to operationalize the African Continental Free Trade Area, assess the socioeconomic potential of the blue economy and conduct market analyses for small and medium-sized enterprises, while keeping in mind the need to protect natural resources;

(f)	Support members of ECA in the development of national tourism strategies, in line with the recommendations set out in the African tourism strategy and provide training on the production of high-quality tourism statistics in the subregion.
18.132	The above-mentioned work will help members of ECA to make progress towards the achievement of Sustainable Development Goals 5, 7, 8, 11, 12, 13, 14 and 17.
18.133	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	National development planning frameworks incorporating and amplifying blue economy policies and strategies;
(b)	Standardized methodologies for tourism data collection and analysis in the subregion;
(c)	Increased market diversification and economic resilience to external shocks, related in particular to the blue economy, the tourism sector and food-related value chains;
(d)	Deeper regional integration and improved connectivity of landlocked countries;
(e)	Higher levels of intraregional trade in goods and services;
(f)	Harmonization of investment regimes and investment promotion strategies, and improved regulatory frameworks governing investment.
18.145	To contribute to the objective, the component will:

(a)	Undertake policy research and analysis on inclusive and sustainable industrialization, regional integration and trade, private sector development, and poverty and inequality, provide technical assistance to members of ECA, regional economic communities and intergovernmental organizations and disseminate best practices at the subregional and national levels in Southern Africa;

(b)	Develop and disseminate policy tools and guidelines for the promotion of inclusive and sustainable industrialization, including value addition, manufacturing and value chain development, at the national and subregional levels in Southern Africa;

(c)	Support members of ECA in the implementation of Vision 2050 of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) and its regional indicative strategic development plan for 2020–2030, thereby contributing to the achievement of Sustainable Development Goals 1, 8, 9 and 10 and related goals of Agenda 2063;

(d)	Collaborate with partners, including the African Union Southern Africa Regional Office, SADC, the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA), the African Development Bank, the African Export-Import Bank, private sector associations and research institutions:

(i)	To strengthen the capacities of members of ECA to advance inclusive and sustainable industrialization and regional integration through implementation of the SADC industrialization strategy and road map (2015–2063), the SADC Regional Energy Access Strategy and Action Plan (2020–2030), the COMESA industrial policy (2015–2030), the African Continental Free Trade Area and the free trade areas of the regional economic communities;

(ii)	To provide technical support for the development of strategies and guidelines for the integration of considerations related to climate change into industrialization and trade policies in Southern Africa;
(e)	Build the capacities of members of ECA and the private sector:

(i)	To address the challenges and opportunities of the green economy in the context of sustainable development and poverty eradication, and to increase productive capacities, in particular, given the situation of energy resource deficiency in the region and the impact of climate change on key sectors;
(ii)	To address the impact of external shocks, by rolling out initiatives aimed at supporting their recovery and strengthening their resilience to future shocks;
(iii)	To leverage digitalization, science, technology and innovation to facilitate growth, business development and enhanced productivity and competitiveness.
18.146	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Enhanced implementation of the SADC Vision 2050 and indicative strategic plan, the SADC industrialization strategy and road map and the COMESA industrial policy;

(b)	Economic diversification and transformation through value addition and the development of sustainable regional value chains, accelerated by transboundary industrial clusters, hubs and special economic zones in selected members of ECA;
(c)	Harmonization of national industrial policies with regional industrial frameworks and integration of considerations related to the environment and sustainability;

(d)	Accelerated implementation of the Agreement Establishing the African Continental Free Trade Area and the free trade agreements of the regional economic communities, increased intraregional trade in goods and services and enhanced regional integration in Southern Africa;
(e)	Increased resilience and competitiveness of the private sector and micro, small and medium-sized enterprises and enhanced participation in industry and trade in Southern Africa;
(f)	Evidence-based policy responses related to poverty, inequality and vulnerability situations in Southern Africa through informed analyses of trends and causal factors.
Programme performance in 2024
Member States adopt the Rabat Declaration on Middle-Income Countries

18.94	Addressing the needs and specific challenges of middle-income countries is critical for the achievement of the 2030 Agenda. Having attained middle-income status, many middle-income countries in North Africa have found it difficult to sustain the dynamism of their economic development and their progress in increasing incomes. This is often associated with growing difficulties in sustaining levels and types of investment that can generate continued improvements in their productivity and adequate employment growth. In 2024, the component, in collaboration with the Government of Morocco and the United Nations Development Programme, organized a high-level ministerial conference that brought together 32 countries, 23 United Nations development agencies and other international and regional institutions to discuss solutions to address the development challenges faced by middle-income countries, including financing gaps. The conference led to the adoption of the Rabat Declaration, which contains a set of action-oriented and innovative solutions and stresses the importance of South-South cooperation and triangular cooperation in addressing the development needs of middle-income countries. The Declaration also included a commitment to develop a strategic action plan for middle-income countries covering the period 2025–2030, in collaboration with the United Nations system and other stakeholders.
18.95	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 18.18).

children.text: Members of ECA integrate the demographic dividend into national budgeting processes

18.107	The West Africa demographic profile offers a vital demographic dividend opportunity that could be more effectively harnessed through the strategic allocation of resources. In 2024, the component continued to strengthen national capacities in budgeting sensitive to the demographic dividend and engaged policymakers from line ministries (e.g. budget, planning, employment, education and health) and members of parliament on applying approaches sensitive to the demographic dividend in their national budgeting processes. This work was undertaken with a view to supporting member States in ensuring that their 2025 national budgets reflect sensitivity to the demographic dividend. As a result of these efforts, three countries (Burkina Faso, Niger and Togo) integrated demographic dividend-related issues into their 2025 budgetary programming documents, laying the foundation for its integration in the 2025 national budgets of those countries.
18.108	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XV).
Figure 18.XV
Performance measure: number of countries that integrated the demographic dividend into their budgetary planning and programming documents (cumulative)
Members of ECA implement projects for improved industrialization and economic diversification

18.120	The year 2024 marked the fourth year of the Decade for Economic Diversification in Central Africa (2021–2030), which has a goal of transitioning subregional economies from commodity dependence to manufacturing and services for sustainable, inclusive and resilient growth. The component supports this shift through a demand-driven programme of research, technical advice, capacity-building, policy support and investment advocacy. In 2022, CEMAC adopted the Master Plan for Industrialization and Economic Diversification. During 2023 and 2024, the component supported member States in the region to operationalize the Master Plan at the national level, including by providing technical advice, hosting communities of practice and supporting the conduct of feasibility studies. As a result of those efforts, four member States (Cameroon, Chad, Congo and Gabon) launched projects in 2024 to implement the Master Plan, covering areas such as wood processing, beef value chain development, industrial fertilizers and the digital economy. In July 2024, the Commission of CEMAC and ECA also signed a memorandum of understanding to strengthen their partnership framework and advance economic diversification in the subregion.

children.text: A new sustainable tourism master plan launched by the Intergovernmental Authority on Development

18.134	Tourism is a significant sector across many economies in East Africa and constitutes a key component of sustainable development. In 2023, the component convened a regional consultative workshop to review lessons learned from the implementation of the Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD) Sustainable Tourism Master Plan (2013–2023) to inform the development of the new master plan. The workshop brought together regional officials from IGAD, national representatives, development partners and stakeholders from the tourism sector to assess progress made and identify gaps to be addressed. This led to the development of a road map to guide the development of the new master plan. Building on the insights from the workshop and through further support provided by the component, IGAD launched the Sustainable Tourism Master Plan 2024–2034, which maps an ambitious path towards enhanced regional cooperation in the area of tourism and strengthening IGAD members’ position in the global tourism market. Building on the success of the previous Sustainable Tourism Master Plan (2013–2023), during which tourism’s contribution to the regional economy rose from 3.8 per cent to 11.4 per cent, the new plan focuses on leveraging IGAD members’ rich cultural heritage, diverse landscapes and unique assets to drive socioeconomic growth. It emphasizes cross-border cooperation, capacity-building, infrastructure development and environmental sustainability, and highlights the need to address issues such as deforestation and marine preservation.

children.text: Advanced integrated development planning in the Southern African Development Community region through digital solutions

18.147	Cooperation among countries on development planning enhances coherence between global, continental and regional development frameworks and national development plans, while also facilitating the monitoring of progress in achieving the agreed development objectives. The component provided technical support and advisory services to SADC member States towards the design and deployment of an online portal for the SADC National Planning Entities Platform, a forum established to foster cooperation on integrated development planning among the ministries, commissions or agencies responsible for national development planning in the 16 members of SADC. The online portal is a tool with multimedia archiving and retrieval functionality for data- and information-sharing on development priorities and emerging issues of common interest to facilitate cooperation among the national planning entities. Furthermore, the component delivered capacity-building training, through which officials (administrators, planners and other technical users) from SADC member States and officials from the SADC secretariat were equipped with technical knowledge and skills for using the digital tool.

children.text: Result 3: members of ECA accelerate inclusive and sustainable growth through increased productivity, diversification and value addition – Proposed programme plan for 2026

18.100	Six of the seven member States in the North African subregion covered by the component are now classified as middle-income countries. The subregion as a whole is characterized by slow growth and relatively high unemployment rates. To address these challenges, the component has been supporting countries to build and enhance capacities for structural transformation, productivity gains, technology adoption and innovation, and human skills development, and to mobilize adequate and affordable finance and address climate challenges. Accelerating and sustaining inclusive growth and job creation is a priority for all North African countries, as evidenced by their requests for assistance from the component in this regard.
Lessons learned and planned change

18.101	The lesson for the component was that member States needed further support to be able to undertake fundamental policy shifts and actions in order to move from an investment-driven economy to an innovation-driven knowledge economy. In applying the lesson, the component will develop knowledge products, provide advisory services and engage in capacity-building to support the development of national industrial policies. Such policies would guide industrial transformation, diversification and value addition and support the building of human and technological capabilities. The component will also provide support to member States in leveraging private capital for investment in renewable sources of energy and in digitalization.
18.102	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XIV).
Figure 18.XIV
Performance measure: number of policy measures adopted by member States to promote increased productivity, diversification and value addition (cumulative)

Result 1: regional performance monitoring and accountability mechanism to monitor and report on progress in the implementation of the African Union road map on harnessing the demographic dividend through investments in youth – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

18.109	The component’s work contributed to the enhanced capacity of an additional 198 national officials in the use of demo-economics and planning tools, for a cumulative total of 405 national officials, which exceeded the planned target of 237. The component’s work also contributed to a stocktaking survey to inform the development of a regional monitoring and accountability mechanism for the implementation of the African Union road map, which did not meet the planned target of five members of ECA establishing a performance monitoring and accountability mechanism for a demographic dividend. The target was not met due to the need for further analysis and advocacy with members of ECA for its establishment.
18.110	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XVI).
Figure 18.XVI

18.112	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XVII).
Figure 18.XVII

Result 3: increased operationalization of national African Continental Free Trade Area strategies – Proposed programme plan for 2026

18.113	The component has supported member States in the West African region in operationalizing their national African Continental Free Trade Area strategies and has worked to foster cross-regional collaboration in this regard. Key examples of support include capacity-building of over 1,200 stakeholders, including women and youth entrepreneurs as key drivers of economic diversification; development of trade information tools and intra-Africa market access tools; and conducting research and analysis to inform member States in the formulation and implementation of their national African Continental Free Trade Area strategies.
Lessons learned and planned change

18.114	The lesson for the component, based on a pilot project involving eight countries in West and North Africa, was the importance of cross-border and cross-regional collaboration. The pilot project enabled these countries to establish strong and inclusive institutional mechanisms to coordinate and monitor the implementation of the African Continental Free Trade Area. In applying the lesson, the component will prioritize peer-learning initiatives and cross-border exchanges for mutual learning. The component will also support member States in West Africa to mobilize additional resources to accelerate implementation of national African Continental Free Trade Area strategies and enhance the capacities of small and medium-sized enterprises to trade under the African Continental Free Trade Area.
18.115	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XVIII).

children.text: Result 3: Central African members of ECA enhance natural asset assessments and capitalization – Proposed programme plan for 2026

18.126	In support of the economic diversification ambitions of Central African members of ECA, the component has actively advocated for greater accounting and capitalization of the subregion’s abundant natural assets. However, investment in natural capital is often stymied by limited data and inadequate assessments, restricting accurate valuations, effective planning and sustainable management. The component supports members of ECA in promoting natural capital accounting in the subregion and in conducting economic impact assessments of natural assets.
Lessons learned and planned change

18.127	The lesson for the component was that sequential capacity-building workshops are more effective at fostering country-level understanding and ownership of quantitative tools than stand-alone knowledge products and publications. This approach is critical, as integrating natural capital accounting can take multiple years and requires high-level commitment. In applying the lesson, the component will implement its newly developed strategy, which is based on five phases: (i) establishing high-level policy commitment; (ii) conducting baseline assessments; (iii) pilot implementation; (iv) developing plans for data integration; and (v) the effective elaboration of economic environmental accounts and revaluation of national wealth. As part of this approach, the component will collaborate with national statistical offices, relevant ministries and other partners to organize training that fully equips officials to independently conduct future analytical updates using natural capital accounting methodologies and tools.

Figure 18.XX

children.text: Result 3: members of ECA implement regional frameworks on tourism and the blue economy – Proposed programme plan for 2026

18.140	Tourism and the blue economy are vital drivers of sustainable economic growth, job creation, biodiversity conservation and resilience in coastal and maritime regions. The component works to strengthen the capacity of member States to harness the potential of the blue economy and tourism. With the component’s support, Ethiopia, Kenya, Rwanda, Seychelles, Uganda and the United Republic of Tanzania finalized tourism satellite accounts, setting the foundation for the sustainable growth of the sector; and Djibouti, Seychelles and the United Republic of Tanzania customized the blue economy valuation toolkit for their national contexts to enable the effective management of blue economy resources. In 2024, the component supported the development of the IGAD Sustainable Tourism Master Plan and the East African Community Blue Economy Strategy and Action Plan.
Lessons learned and planned change

18.141	The lesson for the component was that working through regional blocs such as IGAD and the East African Community can help to accelerate the adoption and implementation of policies at the national level. In applying the lesson, the component will continue to expand its collaborative efforts with regional economic communities, leveraging their platforms for broader reach, synergy and policy coherence across member States.
18.142	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XXI).
Figure 18.XXI
Performance measure: number of members of ECA that operationalized regional development frameworks related to tourism and the blue economy at the national level (cumulative)

Figure 18.XXIII

Result 3: inclusive industrialization through value chain development in Southern Africa – Proposed programme plan for 2026

18.153	Southern Africa is characterized by commodity-dependent economies with low levels of value addition. In this context, value chain development has been recognized as a crucial driver of inclusive industrialization, in view of its potential for expanding production possibilities and enhancing the utilization of both natural and human resources. Value chain development is an important lever of industrialization and therefore an essential contributor to broad-based economic growth and job creation, and is critical for poverty and inequality reduction. The component has been providing technical support to members of ECA aimed at strengthening their capacities to develop and implement policy interventions on value chain development and inclusive industrialization. The component has also produced knowledge products to support value chain development and inclusive industrialization.
Lessons learned and planned change

18.154	The lesson for the component was that the development of regional value chains requires strengthened cooperation among member States, collaboration among development partners and the sustained engagement of the private sector. In applying the lesson, the component will strengthen institutional coordination and continued engagement with member States and the private sector in supporting regional value chain development. Furthermore, the component will place more emphasis on providing technical assistance and capacity-building for the development of regional value chains and related interventions such as the establishment of special economic zones in supporting the industrialization agenda.
18.155	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XXIV).
Figure 18.XXIV
Performance measure: number of Southern African countries that develop policy frameworks on value chain development (cumulative)

children.text: Component 5 – Subregional activities in Southern Africa – Objective

18.144	The objective, to which this component contributes, is to deepen regional integration and strengthen capacities to achieve inclusive industrialization for the reduction of poverty and inequality in Southern Africa.
Strategy
18.92	To contribute to the objective, the component will:
(a)	Develop evidence-based policies, strategies and reforms and provide technical assistance related to economic diversification, fiscal management and resilient and inclusive economies;

(b)	Provide advisory services and hold subregional consultations on the mobilization of domestic resources and the implementation of the Agreement Establishing the African Continental Free Trade Area, in partnership with ministries of trade and the African Union;

(c)	Provide technical assistance and training for selected African countries on migration data collection and analysis and evidence-based policy formulation to mainstream and leverage migrants’ economic contributions, through data collection and analysis;

(d)	Conduct research on challenges facing middle-income countries in North Africa, in particular those relating to development and climate finance, human capital and employment creation in North Africa, with a focus on strategic areas such as digitalization and the green economy in the context of sustainable development and poverty eradication.
18.93	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	Adoption of evidence-based macroeconomic policies and structural reforms by members of ECA to improve fiscal space and enhance productive employment, redirecting resource allocations towards sectors that have a high potential for inclusive and sustainable development;
(b)	Policies and strategies that foster regional integration, enhance productivity and create new jobs in higher-skilled and sustainable sectors;
(c)	Development of evidence-based policies and actions by members of ECA that leverage the contributions of migrants to sustainable development.
18.105	To contribute to the objective, the component will:

(a)	Provide knowledge, tools and policy recommendations on the acceleration of a demographic transition and related implications for sustainable development and climate resilience, including population dynamics, migration, health and mortality, ageing and living conditions, gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls, youth, and sustainable peace and resilience in West Africa, among others;

(b)	Engage in high-level policy dialogues and provide technical support and capacity-strengthening to countries on regional integration issues, including the implementation of the Agreement Establishing the African Continental Free Trade Area, development planning, and the development of budgeting frameworks that are sensitive to a demographic dividend with special emphasis on the empowerment of women and young people.
18.106	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Demographic dividend dimensions mainstreamed in national planning, programming and budgeting processes;
(b)	Deepened regional economic and monetary integration through the operationalization of Vision 2050 of the Economic Community of West African States;
(c)	Accelerated implementation of the 2030 Agenda and Agenda 2063 by member States of ECA and regional organizations, including enhanced capacities in development planning;
(d)	Accelerated implementation of the Agreement Establishing the African Continental Free Trade Area in Africa, with women and young people empowered to seize the opportunities of the Agreement.
18.118	To contribute to the objective, the component will:
(a)	Provide technical assistance and advisory services to members and regional economic communities of ECA in Central Africa on:

(i)	Formulating and implementing national and subregional development plans and economic diversification strategies with a focus on intra-Central African trade and creating a business climate conducive to employment creation and resilient to external shocks;

(ii)	Translating their national strategies for the implementation of the Agreement Establishing the African Continental Free Trade Area into specific and bankable projects, using market access information and trade opportunity data, with a particular focus on the agricultural, energy and pharmaceutical sectors;
(iii)	Transforming transport corridors into development corridors, in line with the Central Africa consensual transport plan;

(iv)	Developing information and communications technology infrastructure and regulatory frameworks required for the digital transition, including support for the establishment of technology innovation centres, in collaboration with the ECA Centre of Excellence on Digital Identity, Trade and Economy within subprogramme 3;

(v)	Harmonizing trade instruments of the Economic Community of Central African States and the Central African Economic and Monetary Community (CEMAC) while developing a unified master plan for industrial development and economic diversification in Central Africa;
(b)	Collaborate with the private sector, subregional think tanks and regional economic communities in the above-mentioned areas;
(c)	Train members of ECA and United Nations country teams in the use of the ECA integrated planning and reporting toolkit.
18.119	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Strengthened regional value chains and industrial clusters, integrated with local economies, and expanded manufacturing and high-value service sectors;

(b)	Integration of the relevant economic diversification-related goals and targets of the 2030 Agenda and Agenda 2063 into national development strategies and plans, common country assessments and United Nations sustainable development cooperation frameworks;
(c)	Increased productivity of local firms and economies, including adoption of new technologies;
(d)	Strengthened role of the private sector in economic diversification in Central Africa.
18.131	To contribute to the objective, the component will:

(a)	Provide support to countries and regional economic communities, through knowledge production, technical assistance, capacity-building and policy dialogues, on the development and effective implementation of their national and regional strategies for the implementation of the Agreement Establishing the African Continental Free Trade Area African Continental Free Trade Area, and the negotiation and arrangements concerning outstanding protocols and instruments on the Area;

(b)	Foster the development of regional value chains in food and agriculture through value chain analyses and the dissemination of information to public and private sector stakeholders about investment opportunities;

(c)	Build the capacity of the private sector to take part in operationalizing the African Continental Free Trade Area, through information and awareness-raising workshops on the functionalities of the instruments and protocols;

(d)	Engage in policy dialogue and provide training to promote transboundary investments and cost-effective trade logistics, including the creation and use of digital platforms and commodity exchanges to reduce asymmetries of information;

(e)	Convene a subregional forum on issues related to the blue economy, including its potential to diversify goods and services and to operationalize the African Continental Free Trade Area, assess the socioeconomic potential of the blue economy and conduct market analyses for small and medium-sized enterprises, while keeping in mind the need to protect natural resources;

(f)	Support members of ECA in the development of national tourism strategies, in line with the recommendations set out in the African tourism strategy and provide training on the production of high-quality tourism statistics in the subregion.
18.132	The above-mentioned work will help members of ECA to make progress towards the achievement of Sustainable Development Goals 5, 7, 8, 11, 12, 13, 14 and 17.
18.133	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	National development planning frameworks incorporating and amplifying blue economy policies and strategies;
(b)	Standardized methodologies for tourism data collection and analysis in the subregion;
(c)	Increased market diversification and economic resilience to external shocks, related in particular to the blue economy, the tourism sector and food-related value chains;
(d)	Deeper regional integration and improved connectivity of landlocked countries;
(e)	Higher levels of intraregional trade in goods and services;
(f)	Harmonization of investment regimes and investment promotion strategies, and improved regulatory frameworks governing investment.
18.145	To contribute to the objective, the component will:

(a)	Undertake policy research and analysis on inclusive and sustainable industrialization, regional integration and trade, private sector development, and poverty and inequality, provide technical assistance to members of ECA, regional economic communities and intergovernmental organizations and disseminate best practices at the subregional and national levels in Southern Africa;

(b)	Develop and disseminate policy tools and guidelines for the promotion of inclusive and sustainable industrialization, including value addition, manufacturing and value chain development, at the national and subregional levels in Southern Africa;

(c)	Support members of ECA in the implementation of Vision 2050 of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) and its regional indicative strategic development plan for 2020–2030, thereby contributing to the achievement of Sustainable Development Goals 1, 8, 9 and 10 and related goals of Agenda 2063;

(d)	Collaborate with partners, including the African Union Southern Africa Regional Office, SADC, the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA), the African Development Bank, the African Export-Import Bank, private sector associations and research institutions:

(i)	To strengthen the capacities of members of ECA to advance inclusive and sustainable industrialization and regional integration through implementation of the SADC industrialization strategy and road map (2015–2063), the SADC Regional Energy Access Strategy and Action Plan (2020–2030), the COMESA industrial policy (2015–2030), the African Continental Free Trade Area and the free trade areas of the regional economic communities;

(ii)	To provide technical support for the development of strategies and guidelines for the integration of considerations related to climate change into industrialization and trade policies in Southern Africa;
(e)	Build the capacities of members of ECA and the private sector:

(i)	To address the challenges and opportunities of the green economy in the context of sustainable development and poverty eradication, and to increase productive capacities, in particular, given the situation of energy resource deficiency in the region and the impact of climate change on key sectors;
(ii)	To address the impact of external shocks, by rolling out initiatives aimed at supporting their recovery and strengthening their resilience to future shocks;
(iii)	To leverage digitalization, science, technology and innovation to facilitate growth, business development and enhanced productivity and competitiveness.
18.146	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Enhanced implementation of the SADC Vision 2050 and indicative strategic plan, the SADC industrialization strategy and road map and the COMESA industrial policy;

(b)	Economic diversification and transformation through value addition and the development of sustainable regional value chains, accelerated by transboundary industrial clusters, hubs and special economic zones in selected members of ECA;
(c)	Harmonization of national industrial policies with regional industrial frameworks and integration of considerations related to the environment and sustainability;

(d)	Accelerated implementation of the Agreement Establishing the African Continental Free Trade Area and the free trade agreements of the regional economic communities, increased intraregional trade in goods and services and enhanced regional integration in Southern Africa;
(e)	Increased resilience and competitiveness of the private sector and micro, small and medium-sized enterprises and enhanced participation in industry and trade in Southern Africa;
(f)	Evidence-based policy responses related to poverty, inequality and vulnerability situations in Southern Africa through informed analyses of trends and causal factors.
Programme performance in 2024
Member States adopt the Rabat Declaration on Middle-Income Countries

18.94	Addressing the needs and specific challenges of middle-income countries is critical for the achievement of the 2030 Agenda. Having attained middle-income status, many middle-income countries in North Africa have found it difficult to sustain the dynamism of their economic development and their progress in increasing incomes. This is often associated with growing difficulties in sustaining levels and types of investment that can generate continued improvements in their productivity and adequate employment growth. In 2024, the component, in collaboration with the Government of Morocco and the United Nations Development Programme, organized a high-level ministerial conference that brought together 32 countries, 23 United Nations development agencies and other international and regional institutions to discuss solutions to address the development challenges faced by middle-income countries, including financing gaps. The conference led to the adoption of the Rabat Declaration, which contains a set of action-oriented and innovative solutions and stresses the importance of South-South cooperation and triangular cooperation in addressing the development needs of middle-income countries. The Declaration also included a commitment to develop a strategic action plan for middle-income countries covering the period 2025–2030, in collaboration with the United Nations system and other stakeholders.
18.95	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 18.18).

children.text: Members of ECA integrate the demographic dividend into national budgeting processes

18.107	The West Africa demographic profile offers a vital demographic dividend opportunity that could be more effectively harnessed through the strategic allocation of resources. In 2024, the component continued to strengthen national capacities in budgeting sensitive to the demographic dividend and engaged policymakers from line ministries (e.g. budget, planning, employment, education and health) and members of parliament on applying approaches sensitive to the demographic dividend in their national budgeting processes. This work was undertaken with a view to supporting member States in ensuring that their 2025 national budgets reflect sensitivity to the demographic dividend. As a result of these efforts, three countries (Burkina Faso, Niger and Togo) integrated demographic dividend-related issues into their 2025 budgetary programming documents, laying the foundation for its integration in the 2025 national budgets of those countries.
18.108	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XV).
Figure 18.XV
Performance measure: number of countries that integrated the demographic dividend into their budgetary planning and programming documents (cumulative)
Members of ECA implement projects for improved industrialization and economic diversification

18.120	The year 2024 marked the fourth year of the Decade for Economic Diversification in Central Africa (2021–2030), which has a goal of transitioning subregional economies from commodity dependence to manufacturing and services for sustainable, inclusive and resilient growth. The component supports this shift through a demand-driven programme of research, technical advice, capacity-building, policy support and investment advocacy. In 2022, CEMAC adopted the Master Plan for Industrialization and Economic Diversification. During 2023 and 2024, the component supported member States in the region to operationalize the Master Plan at the national level, including by providing technical advice, hosting communities of practice and supporting the conduct of feasibility studies. As a result of those efforts, four member States (Cameroon, Chad, Congo and Gabon) launched projects in 2024 to implement the Master Plan, covering areas such as wood processing, beef value chain development, industrial fertilizers and the digital economy. In July 2024, the Commission of CEMAC and ECA also signed a memorandum of understanding to strengthen their partnership framework and advance economic diversification in the subregion.

children.text: A new sustainable tourism master plan launched by the Intergovernmental Authority on Development

18.134	Tourism is a significant sector across many economies in East Africa and constitutes a key component of sustainable development. In 2023, the component convened a regional consultative workshop to review lessons learned from the implementation of the Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD) Sustainable Tourism Master Plan (2013–2023) to inform the development of the new master plan. The workshop brought together regional officials from IGAD, national representatives, development partners and stakeholders from the tourism sector to assess progress made and identify gaps to be addressed. This led to the development of a road map to guide the development of the new master plan. Building on the insights from the workshop and through further support provided by the component, IGAD launched the Sustainable Tourism Master Plan 2024–2034, which maps an ambitious path towards enhanced regional cooperation in the area of tourism and strengthening IGAD members’ position in the global tourism market. Building on the success of the previous Sustainable Tourism Master Plan (2013–2023), during which tourism’s contribution to the regional economy rose from 3.8 per cent to 11.4 per cent, the new plan focuses on leveraging IGAD members’ rich cultural heritage, diverse landscapes and unique assets to drive socioeconomic growth. It emphasizes cross-border cooperation, capacity-building, infrastructure development and environmental sustainability, and highlights the need to address issues such as deforestation and marine preservation.

children.text: Advanced integrated development planning in the Southern African Development Community region through digital solutions

18.147	Cooperation among countries on development planning enhances coherence between global, continental and regional development frameworks and national development plans, while also facilitating the monitoring of progress in achieving the agreed development objectives. The component provided technical support and advisory services to SADC member States towards the design and deployment of an online portal for the SADC National Planning Entities Platform, a forum established to foster cooperation on integrated development planning among the ministries, commissions or agencies responsible for national development planning in the 16 members of SADC. The online portal is a tool with multimedia archiving and retrieval functionality for data- and information-sharing on development priorities and emerging issues of common interest to facilitate cooperation among the national planning entities. Furthermore, the component delivered capacity-building training, through which officials (administrators, planners and other technical users) from SADC member States and officials from the SADC secretariat were equipped with technical knowledge and skills for using the digital tool.

children.text: Result 3: members of ECA accelerate inclusive and sustainable growth through increased productivity, diversification and value addition – Proposed programme plan for 2026

18.100	Six of the seven member States in the North African subregion covered by the component are now classified as middle-income countries. The subregion as a whole is characterized by slow growth and relatively high unemployment rates. To address these challenges, the component has been supporting countries to build and enhance capacities for structural transformation, productivity gains, technology adoption and innovation, and human skills development, and to mobilize adequate and affordable finance and address climate challenges. Accelerating and sustaining inclusive growth and job creation is a priority for all North African countries, as evidenced by their requests for assistance from the component in this regard.
Lessons learned and planned change

18.101	The lesson for the component was that member States needed further support to be able to undertake fundamental policy shifts and actions in order to move from an investment-driven economy to an innovation-driven knowledge economy. In applying the lesson, the component will develop knowledge products, provide advisory services and engage in capacity-building to support the development of national industrial policies. Such policies would guide industrial transformation, diversification and value addition and support the building of human and technological capabilities. The component will also provide support to member States in leveraging private capital for investment in renewable sources of energy and in digitalization.
18.102	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XIV).
Figure 18.XIV
Performance measure: number of policy measures adopted by member States to promote increased productivity, diversification and value addition (cumulative)

Result 1: regional performance monitoring and accountability mechanism to monitor and report on progress in the implementation of the African Union road map on harnessing the demographic dividend through investments in youth – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

18.109	The component’s work contributed to the enhanced capacity of an additional 198 national officials in the use of demo-economics and planning tools, for a cumulative total of 405 national officials, which exceeded the planned target of 237. The component’s work also contributed to a stocktaking survey to inform the development of a regional monitoring and accountability mechanism for the implementation of the African Union road map, which did not meet the planned target of five members of ECA establishing a performance monitoring and accountability mechanism for a demographic dividend. The target was not met due to the need for further analysis and advocacy with members of ECA for its establishment.

18.112	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XVII).

Result 3: increased operationalization of national African Continental Free Trade Area strategies – Proposed programme plan for 2026

18.113	The component has supported member States in the West African region in operationalizing their national African Continental Free Trade Area strategies and has worked to foster cross-regional collaboration in this regard. Key examples of support include capacity-building of over 1,200 stakeholders, including women and youth entrepreneurs as key drivers of economic diversification; development of trade information tools and intra-Africa market access tools; and conducting research and analysis to inform member States in the formulation and implementation of their national African Continental Free Trade Area strategies.
Lessons learned and planned change

18.114	The lesson for the component, based on a pilot project involving eight countries in West and North Africa, was the importance of cross-border and cross-regional collaboration. The pilot project enabled these countries to establish strong and inclusive institutional mechanisms to coordinate and monitor the implementation of the African Continental Free Trade Area. In applying the lesson, the component will prioritize peer-learning initiatives and cross-border exchanges for mutual learning. The component will also support member States in West Africa to mobilize additional resources to accelerate implementation of national African Continental Free Trade Area strategies and enhance the capacities of small and medium-sized enterprises to trade under the African Continental Free Trade Area.
18.115	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XVIII).

children.text: Result 3: Central African members of ECA enhance natural asset assessments and capitalization – Proposed programme plan for 2026

18.126	In support of the economic diversification ambitions of Central African members of ECA, the component has actively advocated for greater accounting and capitalization of the subregion’s abundant natural assets. However, investment in natural capital is often stymied by limited data and inadequate assessments, restricting accurate valuations, effective planning and sustainable management. The component supports members of ECA in promoting natural capital accounting in the subregion and in conducting economic impact assessments of natural assets.
Lessons learned and planned change

18.127	The lesson for the component was that sequential capacity-building workshops are more effective at fostering country-level understanding and ownership of quantitative tools than stand-alone knowledge products and publications. This approach is critical, as integrating natural capital accounting can take multiple years and requires high-level commitment. In applying the lesson, the component will implement its newly developed strategy, which is based on five phases: (i) establishing high-level policy commitment; (ii) conducting baseline assessments; (iii) pilot implementation; (iv) developing plans for data integration; and (v) the effective elaboration of economic environmental accounts and revaluation of national wealth. As part of this approach, the component will collaborate with national statistical offices, relevant ministries and other partners to organize training that fully equips officials to independently conduct future analytical updates using natural capital accounting methodologies and tools.

children.text: Result 3: members of ECA implement regional frameworks on tourism and the blue economy – Proposed programme plan for 2026

18.140	Tourism and the blue economy are vital drivers of sustainable economic growth, job creation, biodiversity conservation and resilience in coastal and maritime regions. The component works to strengthen the capacity of member States to harness the potential of the blue economy and tourism. With the component’s support, Ethiopia, Kenya, Rwanda, Seychelles, Uganda and the United Republic of Tanzania finalized tourism satellite accounts, setting the foundation for the sustainable growth of the sector; and Djibouti, Seychelles and the United Republic of Tanzania customized the blue economy valuation toolkit for their national contexts to enable the effective management of blue economy resources. In 2024, the component supported the development of the IGAD Sustainable Tourism Master Plan and the East African Community Blue Economy Strategy and Action Plan.
Lessons learned and planned change

18.141	The lesson for the component was that working through regional blocs such as IGAD and the East African Community can help to accelerate the adoption and implementation of policies at the national level. In applying the lesson, the component will continue to expand its collaborative efforts with regional economic communities, leveraging their platforms for broader reach, synergy and policy coherence across member States.
18.142	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XXI).
Figure 18.XXI
Performance measure: number of members of ECA that operationalized regional development frameworks related to tourism and the blue economy at the national level (cumulative)

Result 3: inclusive industrialization through value chain development in Southern Africa – Proposed programme plan for 2026

18.153	Southern Africa is characterized by commodity-dependent economies with low levels of value addition. In this context, value chain development has been recognized as a crucial driver of inclusive industrialization, in view of its potential for expanding production possibilities and enhancing the utilization of both natural and human resources. Value chain development is an important lever of industrialization and therefore an essential contributor to broad-based economic growth and job creation, and is critical for poverty and inequality reduction. The component has been providing technical support to members of ECA aimed at strengthening their capacities to develop and implement policy interventions on value chain development and inclusive industrialization. The component has also produced knowledge products to support value chain development and inclusive industrialization.
Lessons learned and planned change

18.154	The lesson for the component was that the development of regional value chains requires strengthened cooperation among member States, collaboration among development partners and the sustained engagement of the private sector. In applying the lesson, the component will strengthen institutional coordination and continued engagement with member States and the private sector in supporting regional value chain development. Furthermore, the component will place more emphasis on providing technical assistance and capacity-building for the development of regional value chains and related interventions such as the establishment of special economic zones in supporting the industrialization agenda.
18.155	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XXIV).
Figure 18.XXIV
Performance measure: number of Southern African countries that develop policy frameworks on value chain development (cumulative)

children.text: Subprogramme 8 – Economic development and planning
Objective

18.157	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to strengthen the development planning of African countries and to improve their capacity to formulate and manage effective public sector policies for structural transformation and sustainable development.
Strategy
18.158	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Deliver training on sectoral, national and regional development and medium- to long-term planning to address the socioeconomic impact of emerging crises, based on updated content on risk-informed economic and social policy formulation and management;

(b)	Promote peer learning and collaboration among African development planners through communities of practice and broaden access to the digitized knowledge repository of the African Institute for Economic Development and Planning;
(c)	Enhance countries’ capacity to monitor and evaluate the implementation of the 2030 Agenda and Agenda 2063, and of national development agendas;

(d)	Foster knowledge generation, cross-fertilization and knowledge-sharing through research products, fellowship programmes, development seminars and high-level policy dialogues, and also through research networks spanning multiple African countries and bringing together universities, think tanks, United Nations country teams and regional stakeholders;

(e)	Support the integration of a gender perspective and youth-related issues in all relevant public policies through capacity-building programmes that also consider issues such as social inclusion, entrepreneurship, employment, the green economy in the context of sustainable development and poverty eradication, innovation and digital transformation.
18.159	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	Increased engagement of development planners and policymakers in policy management and development planning processes that take into account global developments and emerging risks, in support of structural transformation and the increased resilience of national economies to ensure sustainable development;
(b)	More effective formulation, management and influencing of public policies by officials and other stakeholders;
(c)	More inclusive approaches to the formulation of development policies by members of ECA, including through the formulation of macroeconomic and social protection policies.
Programme performance in 2024
Members of ECA design policies to foster regional and international trade

18.160	Intra-African trade is a key driver of sustainable and inclusive economic growth, fostering employment opportunities, promoting gender equality and enhancing the overall welfare of African populations. The subprogramme contributes directly to these goals by supporting the implementation of the African Continental Free Trade Area through targeted capacity-building initiatives. In 2024, the subprogramme provided training to 464 participants on the establishment of inclusive, development-friendly trade arrangements, as part of its efforts to enhance the share of selected African countries in global trade. In addition, the subprogramme supported member States in developing national capacity-building policies to enhance trade within the framework of the African Continental Free Trade Area. As a result of this support, Côte d'Ivoire, Ghana, Kenya, Mozambique, Senegal, Uganda and the United Republic of Tanzania designed regional and international trade policies following country-specific capacity needs assessments conducted by the subprogramme in 2023. The policies focused on creating enabling environments for small and medium-sized enterprises and pathways to foster regional and international trade.
18.161	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 18.31).
Table 18.31
Performance measure

table_content.text: 2022 (actual)
2023 (actual)
2024 (actual)
Seven members of ECA designed policies to foster regional and international trade and create enabling environments for small- and medium-sized enterprises

children.text: Planned results for 2026
Result 1: members of ECA integrate social protection into development planning and economic analysis – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

18.162	The subprogramme’s work contributed to policymakers strengthening their capacity to integrate considerations related to gender equality into economic and social policies, which did not meet the planned target of three members of ECA developing policies that integrate social protection. The target was not met as additional support from ECA was required to translate identified needs into development planning processes.
18.163	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XXV).
Figure 18.XXV
Performance measure: number of members of ECA whose development policies integrate social protection (annual)
Result 2: members of ECA develop a future-ready workforce – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

18.164	The subprogramme’s work contributed to progress towards the planned target for 2025, with 417 officials equipped with skills in strategic foresight and system dynamics and strengthened institutional capacities to establish reskilling and upskilling programmes.
18.165	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XXVI).
Figure 18.XXVI
Performance measure: number of ECA members having established reskilling and upskilling programmes (cumulative)
Result 3: strengthened localized development planning and development financing – Proposed programme plan for 2026

18.166	Localized development planning ensures that solutions are tailored to the unique needs, resources and opportunities of communities, promoting equitable growth and resilience and addressing key issues such as poverty, inequality and climate change. While national, regional and global frameworks provide strategic guidance, many countries face challenges in translating these into actionable, localized plans. This gap is often attributed to inadequate technical capacities, limited data for evidence-based decision-making and insufficient financial resources.
Lessons learned and planned change

18.167	The lesson for the subprogramme was that effective localized planning and development financing require deeper engagement with subnational governments and local stakeholders. Previous capacity-building programmes were often too broad and not designed to address local contexts and priorities. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will enhance its focus on supporting local authorities to design local development initiatives and to integrate lessons learned and findings into their training and planning frameworks. Utilizing a participatory approach, it will also strengthen partnerships with local governments and community stakeholders to co-design capacity-building initiatives on development planning. Regular consultations with local actors and targeted technical assistance will ensure that development strategies are context-specific, while fostering development financing solutions tailored to local needs.
18.168	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XXVII).
Figure 18.XXVII
Performance measure: number of local development initiatives developed by local authorities (annual)

children.text: Subprogramme 9 – Poverty, inequality and social policy
Objective

18.170	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to eradicate extreme poverty and reduce inequality by ensuring that members of ECA have improved policies and strategies for social investment and productive urban job creation.
Strategy
18.171	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Develop analytical knowledge, provide technical assistance and promote regional dialogue and learning for members of ECA on designing national social policies and strategies for the eradication of extreme poverty and provision of social protection to the most vulnerable;
(b)	Generate knowledge, provide technical assistance to members of ECA and organize regional dialogue and learning on strategies to leverage migration for inclusive development in Africa;

(c)	Develop analytical knowledge and provide technical assistance to members of ECA in the regional implementation and appraisal of global agreements, including the Global Compact for Safe, Orderly and Regular Migration, the Madrid International Plan of Action on Ageing, 2002, the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development, the Addis Ababa Declaration on Population and Development in Africa beyond 2014 and the New Urban Agenda;

(d)	Enhance knowledge and skills of members of ECA through technical assistance and facilitating regional policy learning and dialogue to promote sustainable urbanization that enhances job creation, revenues and urban social protection.
18.172	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Enhanced, evidence-based policy options for the provision of social protection for the economically vulnerable population;
(b)	Strengthened responses by members of ECA to address migration and population and development challenges and opportunities;
(c)	Increased prioritization of productive urban job creation in national development planning towards eradicating extreme poverty and reducing inequality;
(d)	Improved economic and financial resilience in African cities.
Programme performance in 2024
Members of ECA monitor the state of migration in Africa

18.173	In line with General Assembly resolution 73/195, ECA conducted the second regional review of the Global Compact for Safe, Orderly and Regular Migration in October 2024, in Addis Ababa. The intergovernmental forum on the Global Compact brought together ministers from 50 African nations, United Nations agencies, civil society organizations and other stakeholders to assess achievements since the first Africa review in 2021, while also identifying regional priorities, gaps and challenges. Delays in implementation of the Global Compact, inadequate economic prospects, poor border control and limited frameworks were among the challenges discussed. To improve governance and policymaking on migration, participants advocated for increased cooperation and harmonized data-sharing procedures. Members of ECA adopted, at the forum, a common African agenda on migration, which will inform the International Migration Review Forum, scheduled to take place in 2026.
18.174	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 18.33).

children.text: Planned results for 2026
Result 1: local governments design resource mobilization policies for improved financial sustainability – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

18.175	The subprogramme’s work contributed to the use by three additional cities (Addis Ababa, Lusaka and Nairobi) of the gross domestic product assessment framework with methodologies, tools, dimensions and indicators to measure the size of the gross domestic product and fiscal performance of cities for a cumulative total of eight cities, which met the planned target.
18.176	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XXVIII).
Figure 18.XXVIII
Performance measure: number of cities that have assessed their fiscal performance as the evidence base for designing improved fiscal policies and planning (cumulative)
Result 2: improved social protection systems for the most vulnerable – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

18.177	The subprogramme’s work contributed to three members of ECA (Namibia, United Republic of Tanzania and Zambia) initiating assessments of social protection systems, which did not meet the planned target of two members having assessed their social protection systems. The target was not met owing to the need for more capacity-building by ECA before assessments could be conducted.
18.178	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 18.XXIX).
Figure 18.XXIX
Performance measure: number of members of ECA that have assessed their social protection systems (cumulative)
Result 3: strengthened national and regional reviews of population-related frameworks to promote sustainable development and leave no one behind – Proposed programme plan for 2026

18.179	Africa is undergoing major demographic shifts in the size, age structure and distribution of its population, which present several implications for sustainable development. Population dynamics, if adequately addressed, can reduce poverty and inequality, thus ensuring that no one is left behind. The subprogramme has supported members of ECA in aligning regional and national solutions with international population dynamics-related frameworks. The subprogramme has also supported members of ECA in reviewing implementation of the frameworks and advocating for African common positions at the global level.
Lessons learned and planned change

18.180	The lesson for the subprogramme was that sustained support on population dynamics is critical for policies to account for population challenges and better respond to the needs of the most vulnerable. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will scale up its technical support to members of ECA in the implementation and review of population dynamics-related international frameworks. This will include capacity-building of policymakers in tracking population dynamics such as migration, ageing and youth to enable members of ECA to adapt their social policies to new and evolving demographic trends in Africa. The support will further include the generation and delivery of knowledge and evidence on population dynamics to inform the formulation and review of social policies.
