children.text: B.	Proposed post and non-post resource requirements for 2026
Overview

18.183	The Economic Commission for Africa (ECA) has embarked on the implementation of its realigned programme of work, as endorsed by its members at the fifty-sixth session of the Conference of African Ministers of Finance, Planning and Economic Development (resolutions 2024/2 and 2024/3). The realignment was proposed as the result of a reflection and analysis that culminated in early 2024 and was focused on deriving lessons learned from the vulnerabilities exposed by the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic and the multiple crises facing the African continent. The ultimate goal of the realignment was to further streamline support provided by ECA to its 54 member States in addressing emerging priorities and challenges related to the timely and effective implementation of the 2030 Agenda and the second 10-year implementation plan of Agenda 2063. The realigned programme of work was presented in the proposed programme budget for 2025 and approved by the General Assembly in its resolution 79/247.

18.184	Armed with its realigned programme of work, and in line with the actions set out in the Pact for the Future, ECA decided to re-enforce its work on technology, innovation and digital transformation; poverty and social policy; data and statistics; financing for development; climate action and food security; and regional integration, economic diversification and sustainable industrialization. To that end, the importance of the new Technology, Innovation, Connectivity and Infrastructure Development Division was reaffirmed as key to the renewed commitment of ECA to the Sustainable Development Goals.

18.185	In support of the realignment efforts, ECA carried out a spending review pursuant to paragraph 20 of General Assembly resolution 77/262, as part of its proposed budget exercise for 2026, also taking into account the United Nations 2.0 initiative of the Secretary-General, in which he had advocated institutional transformation through renewed skills, processes and culture change to ensure stronger impacts and to adapt to future challenges and opportunities. The spending review process was accompanied by a joint integrated resource planning exercise whereby all programme managers came together to discuss and agree on how to secure an optimal distribution of human, material and financial resources (both regular and extrabudgetary) in support of the strategic priorities of ECA. The spending review incorporated results from an earlier workforce planning exercise and included an in-depth analysis of the latest post complement and functional profiles, as well as non-post resource types and distribution. Furthermore, the spending review process was designed to reflect the outcomes of the review of the support architecture of ECA by the Department of Operational Support.

18.186	As part of the spending review process, ECA has reprofiled vacancies resulting from retirements to enhance efficiency and ensure better alignment with the priorities of its member States. For instance, ECA has proposed the abolishment of a P-5 post in 2026 and, in its place, the creation of a P-3 and a National Professional Officer post to help to strengthen the Technology, Innovation, Connectivity and Infrastructure Development Division under subprogramme 3, in line with its strategic priorities. During the spending review, ECA identified the need for additional General Service posts: a Research Assistant for regional integration and trade, Photographers to strengthen digital communication and a Transport Assistant for the subregional office in West Africa. To fulfil those requirements without incurring additional costs, ECA proposes the reprofiling of existing posts. In that manner, ECA is progressing towards a leaner, more agile workforce, optimizing existing resources to enhance efficiency and meet future demands.

18.187	In addition, the spending review provided an opportunity to conduct a deeper review of non-post expenditure trends over the past five years, resulting in a proposal to realign requirements among non-post objects of expenditure, reflecting efficiencies and underutilization in relation to experts, contractual services and furniture and equipment. These efficiencies supported additional requirements under consultants, travel of staff and improvement of premises that are needed for 2026.

18.188	Furthermore, the spending review exercise, including the review and analysis of the Department of Operational Support, pointed to efficiencies that could be realized through the streamlining of staff functions to free up resources that could be redirected towards ECA strategic priorities, through the utilization of existing staff capacity to expand service provision beyond ECA to other Secretariat and United Nations system entities under the Secretariat’s proposed common administrative platform for the Addis Ababa duty station and through the common back office system. Opportunities were examined for maximizing the utilization of the vehicle fleet by digitalizing service delivery, offering transport services to agencies, funds and programmes, leasing low-emission vehicles as part of its fleet and exploring additional efficiency opportunities within ECA, with other Secretariat entities and United Nations system organizations in Addis Ababa and in the regional office locations. To that effect, ECA has, for example, programmed the replacement of its fully depreciated vehicles beginning in 2027 through the use of the United Nations fleet. Additional responses to the findings under the spending review will form part of the future budget proposals of ECA.

18.189	ECA will further invest in innovative technologies, in line with the Global Digital Compact and the related efforts to further mainstream the Data Strategy of the Secretary-General for Action by Everyone, Everywhere. Doing so will allow ECA to improve its programme support processes and ensure efficiencies in its delivery of training and technical support to its member States through e-learning tools, digital platforms and other leading-edge technologies. On a related note, ECA will also expand its use of frontier technologies, such as artificial intelligence, in order to reimagine its knowledge management and communications strategies, with a view to amplifying the impact of its work.

children.text: Figure 18.XXX
Distribution of proposed resources for 2026
(Number of posts/thousands of United States dollars)
Explanation of variances by factor, component and subprogramme – Overall resource changes
Technical adjustments

18.193	As shown in table 18.39 (1), resource changes reflect a decrease of $311,600 under programme support and are related to the removal of non-recurrent requirements under grants and contributions for the Africa Hall project, as approved by the General Assembly for 2025 in its resolution 79/258. Owing to the completion of the project, there are no resource requirements for 2026.
Other changes

18.194	As shown in table 18.39 (1), resource changes under other changes reflect a net decrease of $93,600. The changes will be cost-neutral overall, once the impact on the programme budget for 2027 is taken into account, except for an increase of $22,100 under contractual services related to the higher standard price of the core software package for non-field personnel outside United Nations Headquarters. More information is provided in subparagraph (k) below. The changes include: the transfer of post resources between executive direction and management and subprogramme 2; a net increase of $46,600 under subprogramme 8, relating mainly to additional support for statutory sessions of the African Institute for Economic Development and Planning; a net decrease of $101,200 under programme support, related mainly to reductions in contractual services due to reassessed needs and past underutilization, including as a result of the digitization of documents and workshop materials; and the realignments resulting from the spending review, including the conversion of long-term general temporary assistance positions to posts in order to strengthen mandate delivery in priority areas, and realignments of requirements among non-post objects of expenditure, reflecting efficiencies and underutilization under experts, contractual services and furniture and equipment that supported additional requirements under consultants, travel of staff and improvement of premises, as follows:

(a)	An increase of $1,280,900 under posts and a reduction of $1,540,800 under other staff costs, which relate mainly to the conversion of 11 general temporary assistance positions to posts and a reduced dependence on temporary staff due to internal restructuring resulting from the spending review;

(b)	An increase of $322,400 under consultants, which relates mainly to additional requirements for specialized expertise in addressing the programmatic complexities of subprogramme 5 with regard to meeting key deliverables;
(c)	A decrease of $194,100 under experts, resulting from a reduction in in-person meetings and an increased use of virtual platforms;
(d)	An increase of $88,800 under travel of staff, which relates to required in-person travel, in particular to areas where Internet access is still a challenge;
(e)	A decrease of $299,200 under contractual services, due mainly to reassessed needs and past underutilization, including the digitization of documents and workshop materials;
(f)	An increase of $168,800 under general operating expenses, which relates mainly to increases in non-discretionary expenditure, such as for fuel, water and electricity;
(g)	A decrease of $67,700 under supplies and materials, which relates mainly to the transition to digital workflows and to sustainability and paperless initiatives;
(h)	A decrease of $123,800 under furniture and equipment, which relates mainly to reduced procurement needs based on the current inventory;
(i)	An increase of $135,500 under improvement of premises, which relates mainly to scheduled maintenance aimed at ensuring workplace safety and functionality;

(j)	An increase of $135,600 under grants and contribution, which relates mainly to support for statutory sessions of the African Institute for Economic Development and Planning and support for the subregional office in North Africa;

(k)	A net decrease of $93,600, which takes into account the future increase of $115,700 that will be reflected as a technical adjustment in the proposed programme budget for 2027 for the normalization of the costing for two new posts (1 P-3 and 1 National Professional Officer) proposed for establishment in 2026 and subject to a 50 per cent vacancy rate for the first year, in line with the established practice. The decrease also takes into account the net increase of $22,100 under contractual services related to the higher standard price of the core software package.
Extrabudgetary resources

18.195	As reflected in tables 18.39 (2) and 18.40 (2), extrabudgetary resources amount to $17,187,600, reflecting a decrease of $9,289,100 (35.1 per cent), which is due mainly to the completion of a large number of projects, in particular in the area of regional integration and trade, and anticipated reductions by the largest ECA donors. The extrabudgetary resources would complement regular budget resources and would be used mainly to provide for 75 posts (1 D-1, 1 P-‍4, 5 P-3, 14 National Professional Officer and 54 Local Level) to perform mainly the functions of providing technical expertise and management and administrative support for technical cooperation projects and the office operations of ECA. In addition, non-post resources would be used mainly to provide for financing technical cooperation activities in order to build the capacities of member States in areas such as enhancing regional cooperation and integration through increased trade flows, the implementation of the African Union digital trade architecture and the promotion of regional value chains.
18.196	The extrabudgetary resources under this section are subject to the oversight of the Executive Secretary of ECA, who has delegated authority from the Secretary-General.
Policymaking organs
18.197	The resources proposed under this component would provide for the policymaking organs as shown in table 18.42.

Executive direction and management

18.199	The executive direction and management component comprises the Office of the Executive Secretary; the Office of the Deputy Executive Secretary (Programmes); the Office of the Deputy Executive Secretary (Programme Support); the Strategic Planning, Oversight and Results Division; the Partnerships and Resource Mobilization Section; the Unit of the Secretary to the Commission; the External Communications and Media Relations Section; and business continuity.
18.200	The main responsibilities of the executive direction and management component are:
(a)	Maintaining and managing effective partnerships and collaborating with major African organizations;
(b)	Ensuring that the development priorities and positions of Africa on critical issues are reflected at the global level;

(c)	Determining the overall strategic direction and management of the ECA secretariat, ensuring the optimal use of resources in line with best practices and promoting environmental sustainability and disability inclusion.

18.201	In accordance with the 2030 Agenda, in particular target 12.6 of the Sustainable Development Goals, in which organizations are encouraged to integrate sustainability information into their reporting cycles, and in compliance with the cross-cutting mandate set out in paragraph 19 of General Assembly resolution 72/219, ECA is integrating environmental management practices into its operations. In 2026, ECA will continue to reduce its greenhouse gas footprint and will maintain its greenhouse gas neutrality by offsetting its remaining footprint.

18.202	Information on the timely submission of documentation and advance booking for air travel is reflected in table 18.44. ECA is endeavouring to redouble its efforts to plan well in advance and raise the awareness of programme managers and member State focal points on the importance of early nomination of travellers and the policy regarding advance booking. In addition, ECA continues its corporate agreement with the airlines, which provides for extended ticketing time limits, thus mitigating the impact on the additional cost of late purchases and ensuring compliance in the future.

Programme support
18.217	The programme support component comprises the Division of Administration and the Publications, Conference and Knowledge Management Division.

18.218	The Division of Administration contributes to the effective implementation of the Commission’s mandate by providing administrative and financial support, and promotes compliance with United Nations regulations and rules, policies and procedures. It encompasses the Office of the Director of Administration, the Human Resources Management Section, the United Nations Health Care Centre, the Supply Chain Management Section, the Facilities Management Section and the Finance and Budget Section.

18.219	The Publications, Conference and Knowledge Management Division promotes the visibility and impact of the Commission’s work through its Conference Management Unit, Publications and Documentation Section, Knowledge Management Services Section and Information and Communications Technology Services Section. The Division promotes the visibility of ECA and its knowledge products through the communications and media relations activities and through the rendering of professional conference services to United Nations and non-United Nations entities.

text: II.	Regional Commissions New York Office

children.text: Proposed post and non-post resource requirements for 2026
Overview

18.221	The Regional Commissions New York Office is a joint office for coordination, representation, communication and policy advice at the global level for the five regional commissions: the Economic Commission for Africa, the Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific, the Economic Commission for Europe, the Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean, and the Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia. The Office supports the regional commissions in the effective implementation of relevant legislative mandates while strengthening regional-global linkages.

18.222	In pursuing its objectives, the Office carries out four interlinked functions: (a) providing strategic policy advice and coordination support to the regional commissions to navigate United Nations deliberations and global policy frameworks that have a bearing on their positioning and the implementation of their programmes; (b) fostering cross-regional learning and interregional cooperation among the regional commissions to enhance shared policy solutions and strengthen collaboration; (c) representing the regional commissions in relevant intergovernmental and inter-agency mechanisms to inform decision-making from a regional perspective and provide a link between global and regional perspectives; and (d) communicating the work of the regional commissions with key stakeholders.

18.223	In 2024, the Office played a pivotal role in strengthening the alignment of the work of the regional commissions with global policy frameworks and United Nations priorities. The Office leveraged over 270 engagement opportunities involving intergovernmental and inter-agency platforms to communicate the work of the regional commissions to key stakeholders, foster interregional cooperation, reinforce partnerships and link regional work with global initiatives.
Strategic coordination and policy advice

18.224	The Office provided targeted policy advice and coordination support to the regional commissions on global policy frameworks and processes. By strategically engaging in key global events, such as the Summit of the Future, the General Assembly Sustainability Week, the coordination segment of the Economic and Social Council, the Economic and Social Council forum on financing for development follow-up and the session of the Commission for Social Development, the Office enhanced coordination of the joint work of the regional commissions for improved coherence and policy impact. The joint work included such areas as financing for development, sustainable transport, climate action, biodiversity, critical energy transition minerals and intergenerational solidarity. The Office also provided advice on tailoring global commitments to regional needs and priorities, while leveraging the commissions’ knowledge products and intergovernmental platforms to enhance policy alignment. It supported and continued to advocate for the role of the regional commissions in the follow-up and review of the 2030 Agenda. This included supporting collaboration among the regional commissions on the joint publication entitled “Key messages from the 2024 regional forums on sustainable development”, consolidating and conveying the outcomes of the regional forums to the 2024 high-level political forum on sustainable development, supporting the development of harmonized Sustainable Development Goal progress dashboards and profiling innovative Sustainable Development Goal partnerships.

18.225	Working with the Coordinator of the regional commissions, the Office continued to identify and leverage opportunities in the overall follow-up and review architecture of the 2030 Agenda. In the context of the 2024 high-level political forum on sustainable development, the Office facilitated the contributions of the regional commissions to the thematic discussions on the Sustainable Development Goals, as well as the organization of the reporting session of the five Chairs of the Regional Forums. The Office supported the interventions by the Executive Secretaries during the forum’s main programme and the organization of 11 side events and five voluntary national review labs on the margins of the forum, including a voluntary national review lab on strengthening coherence between the 2030 Agenda and nationally determined contributions.

18.226	Working closely with the Coordinator, the Office also facilitated dialogue among the regional commissions aimed at the preparation of two joint policy briefs, entitled “Road to Seville: reform proposals for FfD4 from the United Nations regional commissions” and “On the road to the Second World Summit for Social Development: contributions from the regional commissions”, as contributions to the preparatory processes for the Fourth International Conference on Financing for Development and the Second World Social Summit for Social Development, respectively. The Office also supported the work of the regional commissions that culminated in the launch of a joint policy brief entitled “Intergenerational relations: creating a world for all ages so that no one is left behind” during the Summit of the Future Action Days. The policy brief contains recommendations aimed at addressing the social and economic challenges of and opportunities presented by demographic shifts towards multigenerational societies across the regions and contributes to the implementation of the Pact for the Future.

18.227	With a view to informing global policy debates, the Office provided strategic advice to the regional commissions in support of their participation in global platforms for joint policy formulation and decision-making, notably the United Nations System Chief Executives Board for Coordination (CEB), the United Nations Sustainable Development Group and the steering committee for the Summit of the Future. The Office also provided substantive support and serviced the biannual meetings of the Executive Secretaries with the Deputy Secretary-General, which ensured that the regional commissions effectively and coherently supported system-wide initiatives, including through tailored support to United Nations country teams on the six transitions and the exchange of good practices. In addition to supporting the Coordinator with regard to participation in the steering committee for implementation of the Pact for the Future, the Office coordinated inputs to the working groups on the implementation of the Pact in such areas as Sustainable Development Goal delivery, reform of the international financial architecture, youth and digital technologies.
Representation and communication

18.228	During the reporting period, the Office organized the annual dialogue of the Executive Secretaries with the Second Committee of the General Assembly on the theme “Building an inclusive and sustainable digital future for accelerated implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals, with a focus on poverty eradication and advancement of gender equality: experiences from the regions”. The dialogue allowed meaningful engagement with the Second Committee on regional perspectives on digital transformation and featured scalable policy interventions and opportunities to maximize its positive contribution to the advancement of the Sustainable Development Goals in the regions.

18.229	The Office coordinated the preparation of the 2024 report of the Secretary-General on regional cooperation and introduced it during the management segment of the Economic and Social Council in July, along with the outcomes of the regional commissions’ intergovernmental sessions. It also facilitated the preparation of the regional session during the Council’s 2024 coordination segment, providing a preview of the 2025 regional forums on sustainable development and highlighting innovative regional solutions to deliver the Sustainable Development Goals at scale and speed. The Office also supported the participation of the regional commissions in the dialogue held during the Council’s 2024 operational activities for development segment, showcasing impactful efforts to address cross-border priorities and strengthen operational alignment across the United Nations development system.

18.230	In pursuit of relevant mandates and in support of the priorities of the Economic and Social Council, the Office coordinated the effective contribution of the regional commissions to special meetings in such areas as financing, taxation, youth, science, technology and innovation, as well as the harnessing of artificial intelligence for the Sustainable Development Goals.

18.231	During 2024, the Office actively contributed to the work of the CEB High-level Committee on Programmes on the use and governance of artificial intelligence and related frontier technologies and the contribution of the United Nations system to the twenty-ninth and thirtieth sessions of the Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. In addition, the Office provided advisory support to the Coordinator and supported harmonization of the positions of the regional commissions in the United Nations Sustainable Development Group, including their support for the Group’s 2024 priorities. It also supported the Coordinator’s participation in the meetings of the Management Committee to advance internal reform and management-related initiatives. The Office also played a role in inter-agency mechanisms established to support preparations for high-level events, such as the Summit of the Future, and the engagement of the United Nations with the Group of 20. The Office circulated weekly reports to the regional commissions highlighting relevant developments and opportunities in the intergovernmental and inter-agency mechanisms, including partnerships.
Partnerships, outreach and advocacy

18.232	During 2024, the Office undertook sustained outreach to member States and United Nations system entities based in New York focused on reinforcing the partnerships with the regional commissions and better linking contributions to system-wide initiatives. Key activities in that regard included the organization of interactive dialogues with the Executive Secretaries and permanent missions in New York, including the Group of African States, the Group of Asia-Pacific States, the Group of Asia and the Pacific Small Island Developing States and the Alliance of Small Island States, and the periodic dissemination of information products highlighting the initiatives, events and publications of the regional commissions. The Office also facilitated rounds of exchanges on regional inputs and policy recommendations with the co-facilitators for the intergovernmental preparatory process leading up to the Fourth International Conference on Financing for Development and the Second World Summit for Social Development. With the aim of amplifying the reform proposals of the regional commissions during the first and second sessions of the Preparatory Committee for the Fourth International Conference on Financing for Development, the Office supported communication efforts related to the dissemination of the policy briefs.

18.233	The Office also contributed to the strengthening of collaboration between the regional commissions and various Secretariat departments in several areas, such as financing for development, migration, population and ageing, transport and social development. In the context of status reporting for the quadrennial comprehensive policy review of operational activities for development of the United Nations system, the Office participated in a series of briefings for member States, demonstrating the progress made in leveraging regional assets to scale up country-level impact. In terms of the ongoing reform efforts, the Office continued to facilitate the inputs of regional commissions to the General Assembly review of the modalities of the Economic and Social Council and the high-level political forum on sustainable development.
Plans for 2026

18.234	The overarching goal of the Office will continue to be supporting the efforts of the regional commissions to accelerate the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals in the last mile to 2030. The programme of work of the Office in 2026 will be informed by the outcomes of the Fourth International Conference on Financing for Development, the Second World Summit for Social Development, the 2025 United Nations Ocean Conference, the 30-year review of the implementation of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action, the thirtieth session of the Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, the United Nations Food Systems Summit +2 Stocktaking Moment and other global conferences scheduled for 2025. The financing for development agenda, including advancing alternative and complementary metrics for measuring progress beyond gross domestic product, reform of the international financial architecture, debt sustainability and international tax cooperation and follow-up to the Fourth International Conference on Financing for Development, as well as driving climate action in the regions, will remain the joint work of the regional commissions and will therefore be key elements of the work of the Office.

18.235	The Office will place an emphasis on elevating the profile and awareness of the work of the regional commissions, ensuring that Member States are well informed about regional policy guidance and briefs to support their decision-making through systematic communication and advocacy efforts targeting key stakeholders. It will also make concerted efforts to strengthen links with work at the global and country levels, notably in recalibrating existing coordination and collaboration arrangements. The Office will also continue to support the follow-up and review of the 2030 Agenda, bringing regional innovations and best practices to global discussions, ensuring that outcomes of the regional forums feed into the high-level political forum on sustainable development, and contributing to the intergovernmental review of the modalities of the Economic and Social Council and the high-level political forum.

18.236	The Office will continue to provide support to the regional commissions on implementing and leveraging the work of the Pact for the Future implementation working groups for Sustainable Development Goal acceleration, as well as the United Nations 2.0 initiative of the Secretary-General. The Office will also continue to serve as secretariat for the joint work of the regional commissions, supporting the identification of avenues for joint work and the promotion of cross-regional learning, strengthening links with work at the global level and advising on enhancing impacts at the regional and national levels. The Office will also contribute to efforts towards the achievement of the Goals across the five regions through the provision of advisory and coordination support and the reinforcement of impactful partnerships.

18.237	The Office will continue to systematically convene and service regular dialogues among the regional commissions at all levels, including by servicing the annual retreat and biannual meetings with the Deputy Secretary-General, with a view to enhancing strategic alignment, internal coordination and collaboration with the United Nations system aimed at operationalizing regional frameworks at the country level through tailored and integrated support to United Nations country teams. The Office will also promote interregional cooperation through joint projects and the exchange of good practices.

18.238	The Office will identify opportunities for engagement and advocacy, including with external stakeholders, coordinate the effective participation of the regional commissions in inter-agency mechanisms and leverage key 2026 moments such as the United Nations Water Conference and the thirty-first session of the Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change for strategic visibility and uptake of solutions and perspectives that foster sustainable development at the regional and national levels.

18.239	In accordance with the 2030 Agenda, in particular target 12.6 of the Sustainable Development Goals, and in compliance with the cross-cutting mandate set out in paragraph 19 of General Assembly resolution 72/219, the Office continues to integrate environmental management practices in its operations, such as by using online meetings, digital document management systems and communication materials instead of undertaking air travels and utilizing paper-based communication. Other measures include adhering to the ban on single-use plastics, optimizing the use of natural light, turning off office equipment at the end of the workday and reducing paper use.

18.240	Information on the timely submission of documentation and advance booking for air travel is reflected in table 18.60. The Office will step up its monitoring of travel and logistics with a view towards achieving earlier planning and improvement in the compliance rates in 2025 and 2026.

text: Annex II Summary of proposed post changes, by component and subprogramme

table_content.text: Component/subprogramme
Posts
Grade
Description
Reason for change
Executive direction and management
LL
Reassignment of one Staff Assistant under executive direction and management as Research Assistant under subprogramme 2, Regional integration and trade

The proposed reassignment of this post from executive direction and management reflects a realignment of post resources with programmatic needs. The incumbent would be responsible for establishing and maintaining databases, independently identifying and monitoring substantive aspects of the subprogramme’s work and systematically retrieving, synthesizing and compiling information from a wide range of sources.
Executive direction and management
Reassignment from Chief of Section, Programme Budget, to Chief of Section, Programme Management

The proposed reassignment reflects an evolution in the scope, complexity and strategic importance of the role. While the current designation focuses primarily on programme formulation and oversight, the responsibilities extend beyond programme budget functions to encompass end-to-end programme management, including integrated planning, resource alignment, risk management and performance monitoring, compliance, strategic reporting and coordination across diverse substantive divisions and external partners. The incumbent plays a central role in ensuring coherence between planning frameworks, efficient delivery of programmatic activities and accountability for results. The shift would also support the broader reforms aimed at strengthening results-based management and improving the delivery of development outcomes. Given the increased leadership demands, interdivisional collaboration and strategic engagement required, the reclassification would more accurately reflect the nature and impact of the post in the current operational context of ECA.
Subprogramme 1, Macroeconomic policy, finance and governance
Reassignment of one Economic Affairs Officer as Programme Management Officer
The proposed reassignment would better align the post with the operational needs of the subprogramme in the critical areas of programme management, reporting and monitoring of results.
Subprogramme 2, Regional integration and trade
LL
Reassignment of one Staff Assistant under executive direction and management as Research Assistant under subprogramme 2, Regional integration and trade

The proposed reassignment of this post from executive direction and management reflects a realignment of post resources with programmatic needs. The incumbent would be responsible for establishing and maintaining databases, independently identifying and monitoring substantive aspects of the subprogramme’s work and systematically retrieving, synthesizing and compiling information from a wide range of sources.
Subprogramme 3, Technology, innovation, connectivity and infrastructure development
LL
Reassignment of one Senior Public Information Assistant as Senior Research Assistant

The proposed reassignment reflects the need for alignment with the mandate and structure of the subprogramme and for increased capacity in areas such as research and coordination of support for ECA members.
Abolishment of one Chief of Section

The proposed abolishment of this post, which is no longer needed, would enable two staff members with technical expertise to work on technology, digitalization and innovation-related issues instead of one staff member at the managerial level. The proposal would thus enhance efficiency and effectiveness by rationalizing and optimally using the limited available resources.
Establishment of one Economic Affairs Officer (P-3) and one Programme Management Officer (NPO)
The proposed establishment would be to support key priority areas, such as technology, digitalization and innovation, in the newly formed Energy, Infrastructure and Services Section.
NPO
Establishment of one Economic Affairs Officer (P-3) and one Programme Management Officer (NPO)
The proposed establishment would be to support key priority areas, such as technology, digitalization and innovation, in the newly formed Energy, Infrastructure and Services Section.
Subprogramme 6, Gender equality and women’s empowerment
Reassignment of one Gender Affairs Officer as Economic Affairs Officer

The proposed reassignment within the subprogramme would coincide with the efficiency-driven approach of ECA operations, aimed at maximizing limited resources through the consolidation of roles. The reassignment would preserve the core functions of the Gender Affairs Officer while supporting member States in advancing gender-responsive economic policies to drive transformation and reduce poverty and inequality.
Subprogramme 7, component 1, Subregional activities in North Africa
Reassignment from Principal Coordination Officer to Principal Economic Affairs Officer

The proposed reassignment within the subprogramme would better reflect the strategic realignment of the subprogramme to increase the focus on economic issues. The incumbent would be responsible for overseeing (a) the formulation of policies and strategies aimed at fostering regional integration, enhancing productivity and creating new jobs in higher-skilled and sustainable sectors; and (b) the adoption of evidence-based macroeconomic policies and structural reforms by members of ECA aimed at improving fiscal space and enhancing productive employment, among other critical tasks.
LL
Reassignment of one Light Vehicle Driver as Senior Programme Management Assistant
The proposed reassignment relates to the need to strengthen programme management capacity within the component, and responds to the increased programme management tasks and responsibilities.
Subprogramme 7, component 2, Subregional activities in West Africa
LL
Reassignment of one Staff Assistant as Transport Assistant

The proposed reassignment reflects the realignment of post resources to facilitate mandate implementation. The Transport Assistant would be responsible for the timely delivery and collection of mail, documents and other official items, meeting and assisting official personnel at the airport, and facilitating immigration and customs procedures to ensure smooth and efficient transit in line with protocol requirements.
Subprogramme 8, Economic development and planning

Conversion of one Principal Programme Management Officer (D-1), one Senior Training Officer (P-5), one Administrative Officer (P-4), one Librarian (P-3), one Associate Librarian (NPO); and one Associate Coordination Officer (NPO) from general temporary assistance positions to posts

The conversion, which is being proposed in the context of the spending review, is related to the need to stabilize the capacity required by the African Institute for Economic Development and Planning. The conversion would ensure continuity, stability and a more effective workforce, while ensuring alignment with organizational goals and long-term strategic planning.

Subprogramme 9, Poverty, inequality and social policy
Reassignment from Principal Programme Management Officer to Principal Economic Affairs Officer

The proposed reassignment within the subprogramme would be to ensure better alignment with the subprogramme’s increased economic focus. The incumbent would be responsible for (a) the provision of enhanced, evidence-based policy guidance to economically vulnerable populations; and (b) the overall improvement of economic and financial resilience in African cities, among other critical tasks.
LL
Reclassification from Team Assistant to Staff Assistant

The proposed reclassification is necessary due to the significant increase in the complexity, scope and autonomy of responsibilities. While the original Team Assistant classification primarily involves routine administrative support and task-based assistance and messenger services, the current duties extend to more substantive and proactive functions, including independent coordination of office administration workflows, the preparation of official correspondence, support for programme implementation processes and liaison with both internal and external stakeholders. In line with the ongoing efforts of ECA to enhance operational efficiency and streamline programme delivery under the reform of the United Nations development system, the incumbent would serve as a critical link between Professional staff, senior management and external partners. The incumbent would be regularly required to exercise judgment, prioritize competing demands and ensure the timely and accurate flow of information. These enhanced responsibilities reflect a higher level of initiative, discretion and knowledge of organizational procedures, which are more aligned with the role of Staff Assistant than that of Team Assistant. The reclassification would thus ensure appropriate recognition of the post’s current contributions and alignment with established United Nations classification standards.
Programme support
Conversion of one Information System Officer (P-3) and one Senior Information Technology Assistant (LL) from general temporary assistance positions to posts

The Information System Officer is responsible for integrating all security system components and providing adequate network connectivity for critical applications and devices. The position is crucial for the proper functioning of security systems and the timely coordination with the Safety and Security Section and the Facilities Management Section. The position was established prior to 2015. 
The Senior Information Technology Assistant provides support in relation to access control system applications, video surveillance, perimeter intrusion detection, the vehicle access barrier system, and badging and visitor management systems. The position was established prior to 2015.
The Senior Staff Development Assistants support the learning and development initiatives related to performance management for staff and supervisors, advisory services regarding performance management and development, senior leadership training, career development and mandatory learning for ECA secretariat staff. The positions are vital to the continued focus of ECA on initiatives related to data, digital technologies, strategic foresight and behavioural sciences. Moreover, they play a continued role in process optimization, automation and steps towards the establishment of the common back office. The positions were established prior to 2015.

NPO
Conversion of one Human Resources Officer from a general temporary assistance position to a post

The conversion, which is being proposed in the context of the spending review, is related to the need to stabilize the capacity required under programme support. The incumbent would design, plan, monitor and provide induction orientation programmes and briefings to new staff members and advise management on training needs.
Reclassification of one Administrative Officer (P-3) to Administrative Officer (P-4)

The proposed upward reclassification results from an increase in responsibilities. The incumbent would be responsible for facilitating preparations for common back office operations, including the establishment of ECA as a service centre, and for undertaking detailed and leading roles in human resource management and administration, data analytics, programme management, budgeting, monitoring and evaluation of business functions.
Reclassification of one Administrative Officer (P-3) to Administrative Officer (P-4)

The proposed upward reclassification results from an increase in responsibilities. The incumbent would be responsible for facilitating preparations for common back office operations, including the establishment of ECA as a service centre, and for undertaking detailed and leading roles in human resource management and administration, data analytics, programme management, budgeting, monitoring and evaluation of business functions.
LL
Reclassification of one Procurement Assistant to Senior Procurement Assistant

The proposed upward reclassification reflects the increased demand for scaling up the capacity and capabilities of ECA in its procurement advisory functions, digital transformation and process improvement implementation, in line with the Secretary-General’s supply chain management reform strategy.
Reassignment from Chief of Unit, Public Information, to Conference Services Officer

The proposed reassignment would ensure alignment with the existing job titles for the Conference Services Officer at the P-4 level under the conference services job family. The role of Chief of Unit, Public Information, as it currently stands, covers responsibilities similar to those of a Conference Services Officer, especially in areas related to the management and distribution of publications and conference materials.
2 LL
Reassignment of two LL Camera Operators to Photographers

The proposed reassignment would ensure better alignment with current operational needs, as cameras are no longer utilized within the printing facility. With the evolution of printing technology, there has been a significant shift from traditional offset printing methods to digital on-demand printing, rendering some previous functions obsolete. The Photographers would support a wide range of high-level meetings, International Day observances and conferences. The positions require proficiency in diverse photographic techniques and the use of advanced lighting equipment, combined with a keen eye for composition, in order to produce high-quality, impactful imagery that meets the Organization’s evolving communications and documentation needs.
LL
Abolishment of one Senior Human Resources Assistant

The proposed abolishment results from some functions being combined and consolidated under the role of the National Professional Officer post proposed for conversion in the Human Resources Management Section.
LL
Abolishment of one Heavy Machine Operator
The proposed abolishment results from the process and workflow optimization efforts of ECA for more efficient deployment of existing staff capacity.

Redeployment of one Senior Medical Officer (P-5), one Medical Officer (P-4), one Head Nurse (P-2), one Senior Nurse (LL) and one Senior Administrative Assistant (LL), from the Human Resources Management Section to the United Nations Health Care Centre

The proposed redeployment is related to the United Nations Health Care Centre, which was a function of the Human Resources Management Section. The Centre is now a separate and independent section, hence the proposal to redeploy the relevant posts.
